IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron overload disorders and iron-restricted anemias are the most common hematological diseases worldwide. Many of these disorders are caused by altered expression of the liver secreted hormone hepcidin, thus considerable interest exists in understanding hepcidin transcriptional regulation. Knowledge gained from this proposed project will help understand the role of Syndecan-1 as an hepcidin regulator and a putative novel therapeutic target that can be used to treat iron-overload disorders and iron-restricted anemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Kidney function is usually estimated from markers that are measured in the blood, but current estimates are less accurate for people with chronic illness, such as those with heart or liver failure, or diverse racial, ethnic and geographic groups. The current project will fill this important gap in knowledge by developing a simple method to estimate kidney function from markers that can be easily measured from a single blood draw and that is more accurate than current estimates for all people across the continuum of health and disease. More accurate kidney function estimates will enable better clinical decision making for patients, more rigorous research designs, and better estimates of the public health burden of chronic kidney disease in the United States.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease is common and causes serious complications – including loss of kidney function. With a goal to protect against loss of function, the proposed studies will investigate a new potential therapeutic target – Par1 signaling. The mechanisms to be examined may also be important in kidney repair after acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it increases the accessibility and, importantly, the diversity of genomic data available to researchers - thereby increasing both equity and the pace of advancement in genomic science - and facilitates Open Science practices in genomic research through a novel technical solution called sign and mask, which simultaneously ensures the integrity of the data and protects the security and privacy of potential research participants. This project will make it technically possible to bring genomic analyses to existing genomic data in the possession of direct-to-consumer service users for the purpose of study recruitment, conduct a robust legal and regulatory analysis for distributed analysis on next-generation genomic sequencing data, and identify the factors that lead laypeople and genomic researchers to accept and use sign and mask and home genetic testing technologies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NHGRI’s mission in seeking to create a more inclusive precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV post-treatment controllers (PTCs) are individuals who can maintain virologic suppression after interruption of antiretroviral therapy and represent a natural model of sustained HIV remission. However, our understanding of the virologic determinants of HIV remission remains incomplete, which is in part due to the scarcity of PTCs identified through any one research center or clinical trial, and in part because of the limited scope of viral reservoir studies that have been performed to date. The main goal of this proposal is to perform an in-depth virologic analysis of PTCs and our overarching hypotheses are that HIV reservoir characteristics can provide mechanistic insights behind their ability to achieve HIV remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although inhibition prevents runaway excitation that can destabilize brain circuits and lead to epilepsy, it must be at least briefly suppressed in order for cortical plasticity and learning to occur. Here we will investigate how a specific type of inhibitory neuron controls cortical activity during reinforcement learning. We hope to discover fundamental mechanisms about stimulus- reward coupling in neocortical circuits that will inform strategies for learning across diverse paradigms and species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis is an inflammatory demyelinating and neurodegenerative disease of the central nervous system. While current anti-inflammatory therapies are effective during the initial phase of the disease, they have limited success as the disease progresses, and in some cases even increase disease severity. Our proposed studies aim to understand how cells of the nervous and immune systems communicate to promote neuroprotection and reveal novel therapeutic targets that prevent neurodegeneration and disease progression during chronic phases of MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dopamine receptors play important roles in human dopamine signaling pathway; therefore, targeting these membrane proteins provide promising therapies for many diseases, including schizophrenia, Huntington's disease, cognitive disorders and Parkinson’s disease. Here we propose to resolve the structure of human dopamine D1 like receptor (D1R), along with the relevant G protein complexes. We expect the structural information we obtain from this study will facilitate allosteric modulation and activation mechanism studies, and therefore benefit rational design of safer and more efficacious therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Elucidating mechanisms that regulate blood cell development is critical for devising novel therapeutics, e.g. for anemia insensitive to erythropoiesis-stimulating agents or GATA2-deficiency syndrome involving immunodeficiency and myelodysplastic syndrome, and innovating strategies to generate blood cells for transplantation therapies. We discovered enhancers essential for blood stem cell generation/function and progenitor cell differentiation, and mechanistic dissection of the enhancers and downstream processes has generated new scientific paradigms and clinical practice to screen for genetic variation in the enhancers. Our multidisciplinary studies utilizing human disease mutations, innovative mouse models, primary cell rescue assay and multiomics will enable testing of how enhancer-regulated networks govern stem/progenitor cells and suppress development of blood diseases in which therapies are critically needed.

PHR: Project Narrative  This research will contribute to a greater understanding of the origin of aortic valve malformations including bicuspid aortic valve that can lead to disease and rupture of the major blood vessel, the aorta. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Humanity is facing an epidemic of interrelated obesity-associated metabolic disorders including insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hepatic steatosis, collectively referred to as metabolic syndrome (Met Syn). Estimates for incidence of Met Syn range from 50-80 million Americans, many of whom will develop morbid diseases including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and liver failure. This project seeks to better understand mechanisms that drive Met Syn thus paving the way to develop novel means to combat this public health emergency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Higher brain functions such as learning, memory and cognition require synaptic plasticity, i.e. the controlled changes in the strength of the connections between neurons. Conditions such as global cerebral ischemia (GCI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) cause not only neuronal cell death, but also impaired synaptic plasticity in the surviving neurons. Based on strong preliminary data, this proposal will elucidate the mechanisms how GCI causes both, neuronal cell death and impaired plasticity. Importantly, this proposal will develop an intervention to prevent cell death and to possibly even restore the impairments in synaptic plasticity. Together, the results will further our understanding of the mechanisms underlying both neuronal cell death and functional impairment of the surviving neurons. Additionally, the results will directly aid the development of a new therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Although calcium (Ca) and iron (Fe) are known to play vital cellular roles in the heart, when there is dysregulation of these two ions there are different pathways that can result in myocardial damage and systolic failure. Under specific biological pathologies, multiple signaling pathways can dictate the susceptibility of cardiomyocytes to contractile failure. We propose that it is an active cross talk and cellular signaling between dysregulation of both Fe and Ca that leads to myocardial contractile failure, ischemia reperfusion injury and ultimately cardiomyopathy (CM). We will identify triggers and signaling pathways that are involved in the observed systolic and diastolic dysfunction and ferroptosis associated with iron induced CM and Duchenne muscular dystrophy associated CM. We will also create an E-C Mitochondria (ECM) coupling 3D network model based on our experimental findings to be used in an interpretative as well as predictive fashion. Our project will therefore address broad scientific as well as clinical questions with regard to the mechanism of clinical myocardial stunning, I/R injury, and CM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Hispanics/Latinos are the largest minority group in the U.S. and have a high prevalence of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors, which is further compounded by the large proportion of Hispanics/Latinos living in poverty and experiencing food insecurity. Mobilizing existing capital (i.e. assets) to promote food security and a healthy diet may contribute to reducing CVD risk among low-income Hispanics/Latinos, but in-depth evidence on the sources of capital influential to food security, diet, and CVD risk is limited. This proposed research will address these gaps by using data from an existing Hispanic/Latino cohort to identify sources of capital that promote food security, a healthy diet, and cardiovascular health, and then apply these results, along with results from qualitative data, to develop a pilot intervention for low-income, Hispanic/Latino adults that targets influential sources of capital to promote cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein misfolding and aggregation underpin several neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. While there are no effective treatments for these disorders, the application of protein disaggregases like Hsp104 is an innovative strategy to tackle these disorders. I aim to understand more about Hsp104’s intrinsic function and develop the technology to engineer Hsp104 variants that dissolve aggregates associated with disease which could simultaneously counter both a loss or gain of function mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea is a serious upper-airway condition in children, as chronic lack of sleep causes many problems such as developmental delay and heart abnormalities; however, surgeries aimed at relieving symptoms are often not successful. In this proposal a combination of fast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) will be used to assess how inhaled air interacts with the anatomy of the airway to predict how this will change after surgery. We believe these techniques will allow surgeons a far better means to predict the best surgical path for each individual patient and will improve their quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The PIWI/piRNA pathway is a highly conserved mechanism responsible for the maintenance of genomic integrity in the germline which is primarily responsible for the silencing of transposons during sperm and egg development. Aberrant transposon activity in the germline can cause DNA damage leading to heritable mutations associated with both infertility and birth defects, and has been implicated in the production of heat- induced DNA damage in developing sperm but not eggs. Understanding how sexually dimorphic piRNA pathway responses to heat stress regulate gene expression, including transposons, in developing sperm and eggs will contribute to our understanding of infertility, birth defects and miscarriage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The need for effective subunit vaccines has prompted the development of combination adjuvants that stimulate multiple pathways of innate immunity for eliciting durable and protective immunity. In this project we will evaluate the molecular mechanisms by which peptide nanofiber adjuvants that induce damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs) synergize with pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) to enhance adaptive immune response against antigens. Successful completion of the project will lead to an improved understanding of combinatorial adjuvant design for developing effective and safe subunit vaccines.

PHR: NARRATIVE Carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae ‘superbugs’ cause life-threatening infections and have been classified as an urgent public health threat. Current antibiotic treatment options for carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae are not sustainable due to the development of resistance and clinical treatment failures. This highlights the critical importance of the current project, which will rationally develop precise combination treatment approaches for these deadly pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to disseminate validated technologies and resources of the National Center for Microscopy and Imaging Research (NCMIR) at UC San Diego to hasten the completion of strategic goals of the BRAIN Initiative for unlocking the role of different cell types and producing maps of brain circuits and ultrastructure at multiple scales. NCMIR will provide specialized molecular probes, novel specimen preparation methods, leading- edge microscopy and imaging technologies, and scalable computational tools to help brain investigators traverse difficult to navigate spatial and temporal scales, deliver new insight into multiscale structure/function relationships, and provide a fundamental understanding of the macromolecular mechanisms underlying brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed experiments determine how local interconnections within the basal ganglia nuclei alter signal processing and oscillatory activity generated within the basal ganglia circuit. Local processing has previously not been taken into account in models of basal ganglia that are used to predict and evaluate potential treatments for Parkinson's disease. A next generation basal ganglia model incorporating this information may improve understanding of basal ganglia disorders and predictions of treatment effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SCN3A neurodevelopmental disorder is a devastating condition caused by mutation of the gene SCN3A (which encodes the sodium channel subunit Nav1.3) and is defined by treatment-resistant epilepsy, severe/profound intellectual disability, and malformation of cortical development, the latter being a surprising consequence of dysfunction of an ion channel. The objective of this proposal, which employs cutting-edge tools and innovative technical approaches in newly-generated advanced model systems, is to investigate the pathogenic mechanisms that underlie epilepsy and brain malformation in SCN3A neurodevelopmental disorder. The long- term objective of this research is to (1) understand the normal role of Nav1.3 in the function of developing neurons and (2) advance from preclinical models to mechanistically oriented treatments or preventative therapies in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oxidative stress has been indicated as one of the most relevant causes of dopamine neuron degeneration in familial and idiopathic Parkinson disease (PD). The first part of the present proposal is designed to mechanistically identify the contribution in PD pathogenesis of the most represented NADPH oxidase isoforms in brain (1, 2, 4) in PD, focusing on specific key downstream pathogenic effects such as LRRK2 kinase activation, α-synuclein dysmetabolism, mitochondrial dysfunction and neuroinflammation. Based on our preliminary data, (not excluding possible implications of NOX1 and NOX4) we expect to address NOX2 as the most relevant pathogenic isoform and, in this contest, the proposed work will also provide evidence on the therapeutic potential of antisense oligonucleotide mediated NOX2 knock down in the brain of rat models of PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  To study where and when plastic changes occur in the cortical motor areas to acquire and retain skilled sequential movements, we propose to manipulate information storage in primary motor cortex (M1) and dorsal premotor cortex (PMd) of non-human primates by injecting inhibitor for protein synthesis or DNA methylation into these areas. We will examine whether the neural trace for sequential movements is gradually consolidated in M1 with extended practice, whether learning processes in M1 and PMd operate in different time frames, and whether M1 and PMd become sites of long-term storage for the acquired sequential movements. The results will expand our understanding of the temporal evolution of the learning and provide information to develop new strategies for acquiring motor skills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is the design, synthesis, and biological evaluation of novel bacterial topoisomerase inhibitors with activity against pathogens which threaten human health, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Multidisciplinary studies involving microbiology, pharmacology, and structural biology will yield fundamental knowledge of the mechanisms of action and resistance of these compounds. These novel inhibitors will overcome previous limitations related to resistance, thereby greatly advancing this class of innovative antibacterials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite the promise of adeno-associated virus (AAV)-mediated delivery of anti-HIV biologics for preventing and treating HIV infection, translating this approach to the clinic is hindered by the high prevalence of anti-AAV neutralizing (n) antibodies (Abs) in humans. To tackle this barrier, we will identify the least prevalent AAV serotypes in people living with HIV in the epicenter of the HIV/AIDS epidemic and assess whether depletion of circulating IgG molecules can reduce pre-existing anti-AAV Ab levels sufficiently to allow AAV-mediated delivery of anti-HIV biologics to nonhuman primates. If successful, this research could bring us closer to testing the efficacy of AAV-based immunotherapies in people, regardless of their AAV serostatus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Repetitive behaviors are commonly observed in numerous disorders such as obsessive-compulsive disorder, Tourette’s syndrome, and autism spectrum disorders and there is a critical need to identify better treatment strategies to help patients with these disabling symptoms. In recent years, highly selective positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) for M4 muscarinic receptors have emerged as exciting new therapeutic agents that can modulate striatal circuitry in the brain that is heavily implicated in regulating repetitive behaviors in both animal models and human patients. We propose a series of studies aimed at elucidating the utility of M4 PAMs as novel therapeutics to treat these symptoms and test the hypothesis that M4 PAMs can reduce repetitive behaviors in preclinical animal models by normalizing striatal neurotransmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microscopic colitis, a relapsing inflammatory disease of the large intestine caused by a dysregulated immune response to changes in the gut luminal microenvironment, affects approximately 1 in 115 females and 1 in 286 males over a lifetime but has no FDA-approved therapies. Diet is the largest contributor to the gut luminal microenvironment but remains unexplored in microscopic colitis; as such, this proposal comprehensively examines the role of dietary patterns and downstream plasma and gut-microbiome-derived metabolites in disease pathogenesis and treatment outcomes. This proposal represents a critical step to advancing our understanding of microscopic colitis pathogenesis, with the goal of ultimately advancing treatment strategies for this debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy of infancy with migrating focal seizures (EIMFS) is a condition associated with very severe intellectual disability. It is caused by mutations in the KCNT1 gene, which encodes the Slack potassium channel, a protein that regulates both firing patterns and the translation of new mRNAs in neurons. The experiments in this proposal will determine how such mutations alter the excitability of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in the cerebral cortex and how they control the synthesis of other types of channels, information critical to the development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple Sclerosis is a devastating demyelinating disease that effects millions of Americans with limited therapeutic success. Our lab has identified inhibitors of select enzymes in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway to be novel targets to inhibit to promote re-myelination. This proposal seeks to investigate this pathway further to identify other potential targets within the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway and the overall mechanism of these sterols to provide novel therapeutic angles.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Polypropylene slings/meshes are commonly used in the surgical treatment of women with urinary incontinence and/or pelvic organ prolapse. However, women with diabetes experience ~5-fold increase of mesh- related complications than the general population. The overall goal of this proposal is to determine whether hyperglycemic memory in innate immune cells negatively impact the long-term mesh outcomes despite peri- operative glycemic control, findings from which will guide future preventive strategies to improve the health care of women with diabetes receiving prosthesis-aided surgeries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality, characterized by persistent inflammation following cardiac injury leading to dysfunctional remodeling. This project aims to understand the role of newly discovered non-coding RNA known as circular RNAs in the regulation of monocyte/macrophage biology in cardiac injury and repair. Findings from this proposed study may potentially be crucial in understanding new mechanisms of inflammation-regulated circular RNAs as new therapeutic targets for cardiac repair and remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because elderly patients with mild cognitive impairment and early-stage dementia are frequently underdiagnosed, posing significant burden on patients, families, and healthcare systems. Development of a novel screening algorithm built on easily accessible data generated in routine patient-clinician encounters has a strong potential to identify these patients, promoting timely care and preventing negative outcomes, particularly emergency department visits and hospitalizations. The proposed study is aligned with one of the National Institute of Aging’s Strategic Directions for Research (2020-2025), “Develop improved approaches for the early detection and diagnosis of disabling illnesses and age-related debilitating conditions.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deuterium metabolic imaging (DMI) is a novel 3D method that can noninvasively map metabolism of non- radioactive, deuterium-labeled substrates in healthy or diseased brain. Choline is an essential nutrient that is often taken up and metabolized at a higher level in tumors than in normal tissue. Deuterium-labeled choline is a promising imaging probe that can be combined with DMI to map choline uptake and metabolism in brain tumors in vivo, and inform on tumor aggressiveness and treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Caregiving for an aging parent is often stressful and can impact caregivers’ health. We examine if this is particularly true for adult caregivers with histories of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs). Investigating the experience of filial caregivers using the life course perspective can offer unique solutions to relieve caregivers’ stress and burden, ultimately promoting their health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular mechanisms that contribute to maintenance and modulation of body temperature under normal and adaptive conditions remain to be fully elucidated. The objective of this proposal is to use hibernation as a naturalistic model to understand basic mechanisms that underlie reversible hypothermia in mammals. Insights gleaned from these studies will facilitate the development of pharmacological agents for hypothermia induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic distress has long been linked with increased risk of multiple chronic age-related diseases, including cardiovascular disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias. Systematically dysregulated metabolic processes may be one mechanism linking high distress levels to later life poor health. Direct evidence that altered patterns of blood metabolites commonly occur in response to chronic distress in diverse populations will provide valuable information on biological pathways that explain how chronic distress leads to poorer cardiometabolic and cognitive health as people age, and may suggest novel targets for more effective intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States, and is frequently initiated or exacerbated by stress. In fact, both chronic stress exposure and heightened physiological reactivity to acute psychological stress are associated with increased cardiovascular mortality. Our preliminary data indicate that the rodent infralimbic prefrontal cortex reduces physiological stress responses and the goal of this proposal is to determine whether infralimbic projections to the brainstem prevent stress-induced cardiovascular pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Stress is linked to Alzheimer’s disease risk and progression but the ways by which stress increases Alzheimer’s disease risk is not well understood. This project will assess how exposure to a single stressful event affects biomarkers related to Alzheimer’s disease. Increasing our understanding of how a single stressful event affects Alzheimer’s disease biomarkers will help uncover how stress exposure earlier in life increases the risk for Alzheimer’s disease later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 250,000 Americans develop acute pulmonary embolism each year, and nearly all are admitted to the hospital despite clinical evidence and guidelines recommending management at home for up to half of these patients. This study will evaluate a program to help Emergency Medicine clinicians in a diverse set of Michigan hospitals identify and discharge patients with acute pulmonary embolism for safe management at home. State-of-the-art implementation science frameworks and behavior change theories will be used to inform tailoring and multi-level evaluation, and set up infrastructure for national program dissemination that will help avoid nearly 100,000 unnecessary hospital admissions annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The brains of individuals with Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, and a significant portion of those with Alzheimer's disease gradually develop abnormal protein deposits called Lewy bodies, but it is not known how they form and contribute to disease. This study uses a recently discovered method that causes brain cells to form these lesions, allowing us to investigate which neurons in the brain are most affected by this disease process and how this type of pathology impairs the survival of these neurons. Better understanding of these processes would lead to a better understanding of disease progression and accelerate the development of new therapies for a host of neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's, dementia with Lewy bodies, and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mosquito-borne flaviviruses present a significant global health burden, with Dengue, West Nile and Zika viruses causing millions of infections and thousands of deaths annually. A better understanding of the viral surface will aid structure-based pharmaceutical design efforts to develop more effective treatments and safer vaccines. This proposal describes research to characterize poorly understood heterogeneity in the viral surface lattice of E proteins, combining novel technologies and analyses to improve structural models and antibody neutralization stoichiometry predictions, and clearly establishing which lattice arrangements are most important for infectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH) occurs in approximately 50,000 patients per year in the U.S. and causes considerable morbidity and mortality. Aneurysmal rupture triggers a robust and dysregulated systemic proinflammatory response; however, the systemic metabolic response has not been described. This project seeks to define the systemic metabolic abnormalities occurring early after aSAH using a metabolomic based approach and will investigate metabolically targeted treatments that improve innate immune system oxidative metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Huntington’s disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative disorder exhibiting progressive motor and cognitive decline where medium spiny neurons (MSNs) of the striatum are preferentially affected. This proposal aims to determine the molecular pathways that lead to MSN transcriptional dysregulation and degeneration, and to identify potential therapeutic targets to ameliorate or even prevent MSN death during HD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Head CT has been widely used in pediatric patients for the diagnosis of cranial fractures in head trauma and cranial suture patency in craniosynostosis, a congenital disability defined by a prematurely fused cranial suture. Unfortunately, these pediatric patients are particularly vulnerable to ionizing radiation from CT scans. Moreover, sedation is commonly used to reduce motion artifacts in children. Our proposal will develop a motion-robust, fast, and fully automated approach to perform high resolution 3D cranial bone imaging using MR as a safe alternative. The proposed research is relevant to public health as it will have a profound impact on pediatric patients by reducing the risks associated with ionizing radiation and sedation for cranial bone imaging. If successful, this study will achieve a goal set by the National Cancer Institute, American College of Radiology, and US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) by reducing radiation exposure in children from head CT scans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current surgical options for intractable epilepsy result in continued seizures in 30-60% of cases. New research, including our own, suggests that quantitative analysis of the interictal EEG — time periods between seizures — can localize seizure generators and may help improve surgical planning. The goals of this study are to determine the spatiotemporal characteristics of two alternate quantitative methods of analyzing interictal EEG, to test whether these methods accurately localize seizure generators, and to determine if probing the interictal EEG with electrical stimulation improves localization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF) is a common syndrome with few effective therapies, due to its multiple phenotypes and our poor understanding of its pathobiology. The current proposal will use bioinformatics to analyze cell-specific and metabolic abnormalities in heart tissue and blood samples from patients with HFpEF. The work is highly translational and will guide efforts to match subgroups to appropriate precision therapies for this major unmet medical need.

ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because of the harms/benefit ratio for prostate cancer screening, clinical guidelines generally recommend against universal PSA screening for men but do call for shared decision making (SDM). SDM involves discussing the benefits and harms of medical interventions and incorporating patient preferences into decisions. The next frontier in cancer screening is a new paradigm of precision screening, in which an individual’s genetic make-up may be used to stratify their level of future cancer risk and inform whether, how early, and how often they should be screened. Both precision screening and SDM are part of the Cancer Moonshot v2.0. This also has implications for SDM, as Veterans and providers will need to integrate this new type of information into decisions. We propose to identify the most effective ways by which primary care in VHA can make shared decision making a routine part of their usual care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: VA is a national leader in the provision of high-quality hospice and palliative care, particularly in VA Community Living Centers (CLCs). Yet the demand for CLC-based hospice care has outpaced supply, a gap that is expected to increase with the aging of the Veteran population. To address this need, VA contracts with community nursing homes (CNHs) and hospice agencies to provide CNH-based hospice care to Veterans. Our preliminary work has revealed that quality ratings of EOL care provided in CNHs are soberingly lower than in VA CLCs. Thus, VA must identify ways to improve quality of EOL care in CNHs. This novel project uses a mixed methods design to develop a rich understanding of the structural characteristics and care processes that are associated with the provision of high-quality CNH-based hospice care. The results will be used to inform policies and practices that improve the quality of EOL care provided in CNHs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a major health concern and places an enormous burden on society and healthcare systems in the U.S., especially in rural areas. This project aims to plan and test auricular point acupressure self- management (APA-SM) integrated into primary care. We will conduct a real-world trial to evaluate clinical effectiveness, implementation outcomes, and cost-effectiveness toward revolutionizing pain management particularly for rural populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans develop Parkinson’s disease at a higher rate than the general population. Parkinson’s disease is a progressive condition with no known cure. Drug treatments work for a while but often fail as the disease progresses. Deep brain stimulation can help alleviate motor symptoms but requires invasive implant surgery, and side effects can limit its effectiveness. The goal of this project is to develop better ways to treat motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease using somatosensory stimulation as a less invasive or non-invasive way to produce beneficial changes in brain network signaling. In this study, a rat model of Parkinson’s disease will be used to compare different stimulation patterns and sensory targets and if stimulation should be applied continuously or in response to certain brain states. The technology developed and refined on this grant could provide a safer way to more effectively reduce Parkinson’s symptoms with fewer side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-healing bone fractures are a significant source of personal, economic, and healthcare system burden, especially in elderly populations. mRNA is emerging as a new strategy for regenerative medicine but may be improved with biomaterial carriers. This proposal will characterize mineral coated microparticles as a vehicle to decrease the reliance of mRNA therapeutics on freezers and for mRNA stimulation of bone defect healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proper response of the immune system to pathogens is governed by complex, network-like interactions among various types of cells and their associated communication mediators. Computational systems modeling provides the ability to describe and interrogate the dynamics of these complex systems with the objective to identify and design more sophisticated and effective drug therapies. This funding will enable us to continue to develop a “Virtual Immune System” -- a multi-cellular and multi-scale model of the human immune system -- to study the properties of the immune system, investigate immune-related diseases, and make predictive modeling software technologies more accessible to the broad scientific community (including immunologists, computational biologists, and translational researchers).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)—i.e., discharging infected ears—is a significant world health problem with no effective therapy that is the most common cause of permanent hearing loss among children in the developing world. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA), a leading bacterial cause of CSOM, invades the middle ear and establishes itself into a difficult-to-treat biofilm, but it is not yet known how this bacterial invasion leads to inner ear hearing loss. We aim to use our novel CSOM mouse model to determine the timing and nature of structural changes and macrophage distribution occurring within the cochlea, identify potential hair cell toxins and macrophage inducers, and investigate the contributions of resident and migrating macrophages to CSOM hair cell death and sensory hearing loss, which may lead to new strategies for preventing permanent hearing loss in CSOM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current methods of ascertaining complications after percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI) or ‘stent procedures’ are resource intensive and inadequate. This proposal aims to create and validate hybrid algorithms which use structured and unstructured data from the electronic health record leveraging natural language processing techniques, to reliably detect two important post-PCI events – in-hospital bleeding and 1- year target lesion revascularization. These algorithms will be incorporated into an automated routine which generates scheduled reports on these complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Pertussis (aka whooping cough) is a serious childhood disease that is re-emerging in developed countries despite high vaccine coverage, due to inadequacies of current acellular (aP) pertussis vaccines. We are investigating how two major Bordetella virulence factors, filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) and adenylate cyclase toxin (ACT), cooperate to minimize inflammation and inactivate host phagocytes, contributing to bacterial persistence in the lower respiratory tract. Our results will provide insight needed to develop more efficacious vaccines and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project narrative Arm and hand function is impaired in a number of veterans with cervical spinal cord injury. This proposal aims to use transcutaneous electrical spinal stimulation (TESS) in a task-specific manner to maximize the recovery of arm and hand function and combined this novel approach with motor training using a closed-loop control strategy. Because deficits in hand control are a major problem after stroke, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, multiple sclerosis, and other motor disorders, our work may also be relevant for veterans with other lesions of the CNS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health relevance/Narrative Defects in the primary cilia modify progression of cystogenesis in polycystic kidney disease models in mice, but the identity and role of ciliary regulators are unknown. This project addresses several key issues in signaling generated by primary cilium, including mechanisms underlying trafficking of proteins to the ciliary membrane, and will use orthologous mouse and cell culture models to evaluate the role of ciliary trafficking in pathogenesis of polycystic kidney disease. Testing the mechanisms of ciliary trafficking of potential regulators and role of cilium-generated signaling with respect to kidney cystogenesis could potentially provide molecular targets for ameliorating disease progression in humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Leigh’s syndrome is a devastating newborn neurodevelopmental mitochondrial disorder. This is a genetically heterogeneous disorder always associated with cellular lesions that affect mitochondrial bioenergetics. This project will examine the molecular mechanism underlying two forms of LS due to mutations in LRPPRC or TACO1, which are involved in different aspects of mitochondrial RNA metabolism and gene expression. These studies will uncover the role of these proteins on mitochondrial mRNA folding and test whether accumulation of aberrant RNA secondary structures is a common theme leading to pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: There is an unmet need for new therapies to reduce the high morbidity and mortality associated with ARDS. We propose a systematic analysis of protein ubiquitination networks in ARDS. Specifically, we will focus on identifying novel ubiquitin pathways that modulate the inflammatory cascade, the function of mitochondria/mitophagy, and the activation of DAMPs/inflammasome in the lung, in the effort to develop novel therapeutics for ARDS. This proposal will lay the groundwork for future studies aimed at the discovery of small molecules targeting protein ubiquitination pathways in ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer cells use various mechanisms to manage their survival such as repairing DNA damage resulting from unchecked DNA replication. Moreover, the ability of cancer cells to repair radiation or chemotherapy drug- induced DNA damage also serves as one of the mechanisms for therapy resistance. Consistent with this, several DNA repair factors are reported to be overexpressed in cancer patients. Therefore, drugs that are capable of suppressing DNA repair responses of cancer cells will have promising therapeutic outcomes. This study proposes to develop a novel inhibitor that is derived from a FDA approved anti-depressant, which will suppress breast cancer growth and metastasis by inhibiting key proteins such as FOXM1, which are involved in DNA repair pathway. Furthermore, this inhibitor has potential to enhance the efficacy of the current chemotherapy drugs and prolong survival of breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reovirus (ReoV) is an enteric dsRNA virus which can infect a wide range of mammals and is often used in oncolytic research. I have found that ReoV induces ZBP1-dependent necroptosis and apoptosis, though the mechanism by which this occurs is largely unclear. Identifying how ZBP1 is activated and assessing the importance of ZBP1-induced cell death to ReoV clearance and pathogenesis will have potentially important ramifications for the treatment of ReoV-initiated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly population, with a prevalence that is expected to double by 2050 and limited treatment options currently available. Given the high costs, long timelines, and high clinical failure rates of new AD drugs, drug repurposing has emerged as a strategy to increase success in AD drug development. This project proposes two independent approaches leveraging novel genetics and informatics methods to identify drug repurposing candidates for AD in a high-throughput manner, both combined with clinical validation of candidate drugs using data from electronic health records and healthcare claims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinal ganglion cell (RGC) injury in mammals leads to irreversible vision loss, however, in zebrafish lost RGCs are robustly regenerated due to endogenous stem cells present in all vertebrate retinas, Müller glia. We created a novel zebrafish model designed to reveal cellular, chemical, and genetic factors regulating RGC regeneration in fish and will draw comparisons of these factors to a mouse model where regeneration is absent. These studies are designed to provide insights necessary to stimulate regenerative potential in the mammalian retina, thus supporting the development of transformative therapeutics for restoring visual function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Microglia-neuron crosstalk is critical for the formation, refinement, and survival of synaptic connections in the brain. The microglial receptor colony-stimulating factor 1 has two ligands, one of which, interleukin-34 (IL34), is produced by neurons, however its role in microglia function is unknown. Disrupted IL34 signaling is implicated in neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases that are characterized by synapse loss/dysfunction, thus my project aims to elucidate how IL34 expression is regulated in neurons and what IL34 does to impact microglial interactions with neurons in development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance The relevance of this application is rooted in the fundamental translational biology of how the immune system impacts cardiac disease presentation and resolution. It is very important to understand and define the basic science mechanisms underlying how the adult human heart heals after ischemic injury and how the immune system intimately regulates this process. Here we will attempt to define therapeutic applications for directly altering the immune response in the heart during and after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our large scale genetic investigation of Huntington's disease (HD) patients revealed that the timing of onset is significantly delayed in subjects carrying duplicated CAA-CAG interruption in HTT gene, due to decreased length of uninterrupted CAG repeat and potentially reduced somatic repeat expansion. In order to advance this promising human-validated therapeutic target, we propose to determine potential of base editing strategies to convert CAG at various locations in the huntingtin CAG repeat to CAA. Our human-based therapeutic base editing strategies for CAG-to-CAA conversion, which do not change huntingtin protein sequence, can be applied to all HD patients and are expected to produce very strong effects, representing a significant and clinically relevant advancement toward development of effective and safe treatments for HD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammation is central to many chronic conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, atherosclerosis and inflammatory skin disease. Increased levels of secreted phospholipase A2 are observed in these conditions, resulting in cleavage of membrane phospholipids into lysophospholipids and fatty acids. In this proposal, we investigate the recognition of these phospholipid breakdown products by T cells, which will open up avenues of investigation into the functions of lipid-specific T cells in the context of inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with multiple brain metastases, a cancer which has spread to multiple places in the brain, have poor survival or quality of life after single fraction stereotactic radiosurgery or whole brain radiotherapy. We will develop and study a new treatment strategy for multiple brain metastases using spatial and temporal fractionated stereotactic radiosurgery by frameless GammaKnife. The new procedure uses artificial intelligence to optimize and manage the treatment to improve patients’ survival and quality of life after the treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD), the number one killer in men and women, is associated with the prevalence of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Consumption of fructose, primarily found in sugar-sweetened beverages and processed foods, is a major risk factor for development of both NAFLD and CVD. The primary goal of this proposal is to determine the mechanisms by which fructose increases cholesterol levels, which will yield insight into novel therapeutic options for NAFLD and associated CVD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The proposed research is focused on innovative instrumentation that will enable fundamental advances in the field of Dynamic Nuclear Polarization (DNP) NMR at high magnetic fields, making this powerful technique far more readily available and useful to the national and international biomedical research communities. DNP NMR has been demonstrated to increase the signal to noise ratio by a factor of more than 400 in NMR spectroscopy and has foremost applications in the study of structural biology of membrane, soluble and amyloid proteins, but the DNP signal falls off at very high magnetic field. Our pioneering research will build and demonstrate the instrumentation needed for improved signal intensities in high magnetic field DNP NMR by developing pulsed gyrotron oscillators and the necessary switches and modulation techniques for controlling the gyrotron output.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to investigate how the allosteric regulation of the Sodium-Calcium Exchanger (NCX) by intracellular sodium affects heart function. NCX influences heart contractility by extruding cytoplasmic Ca2+ and alterations in its activity are associated with pathological conditions such as chronic heart failure and ischemia- reperfusion. Understanding NCX mechanisms of regulation and their potential physiological impact will assist in designing ways to modulate NCX activity, helping advance knowledge of treatment for heart failure and in developing new therapeutic and pharmacological applications.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Few neurological conditions are as complex and devastating as stroke. It is a major cause of disability in the United States and in the aging population of veterans. While there have been important strides taken toward optimizing functional recovery, a substantial proportion of stroke survivors continue to experience long-term motor disability. The goal of this proposal is to develop a better neurophysiological model of the circuit basis of recovery and to use this to test new therapeutic approaches. We hope to use this knowledge to create novel therapies to promote motor recovery. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public is concerned about the high rates of lung cancer from environmental exposure to tobacco smoke and radon. We will identify geological and atmospheric conditions that increase radon intrusion into homes, translate this knowledge into increased residential awareness of lung cancer risk, facilitate home radon testing and report back, and increase access to affordable and adequate radon mitigation. By bringing residents and traditional (e.g., public libraries) and non-traditional (e.g., low interest loan providers) organizations to the table to reduce radon exposure, the way communities address environmental health issues will be transformed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and lethal brain cancer, and there is a dire need for new therapeutic approaches. We previously showed that Diacylglycerol kinase-α (DGKα) is a potential therapeutic target for GBM, with DGKα inhibition having the exciting potential to directly attack cancer cells but possibly also boost the anti-tumor immune response. More recently we showed that the abandoned drug ritanserin could be repurposed as a DGKα inhibitor, potentially accelerating the clinical development of this strategy. Ritanserin has shown greater promise in combination with other agents. Our newest results show that intermittent dosing of ritanserin—with a low dose every two to three days—is extremely effective in a mouse model of GBM with an intact immune system. We have also found a potential new mechanism of DGKα inhibition in the immune system. This proposal will test the effects of DGKα inhibition on these immune cells, as well as following up on the mechanisms and activity of intermittent low dosing of DGKα inhibitors, alone and combined with other agents, in treating GBM in mouse models. The results should inform the clinical development of DGKα inhibition as a novel treatment for GBM and identify new mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human genome sequence lays the foundation for identifying disease‐associated mutations and genetic variations, insights into gene regulation, genomic tools, and therapeutics. We and others discovered a novel class of long non‐coding (lnc)RNAs called DoGs (for “downstream of genes”) expressed when cells experience stress (e.g. heat, high salt, oxidative stress, viral infection and cancer); DoGs are rapidly produced when transcription of normal genes aberrantly continues. We will apply the most recent advances in RNA sequencing technology and functional genomic approaches to discover the role(s) of DoG RNAs in cell physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a debilitating and chronic psychiatric illness associated with severe personal and public costs that affects approximately 6.4% of the U.S. population (~21 million Americans). Although PTSD is characterized by inflexible emotion regulation across experiential, behavioral, and physiological systems, little is known about how emotion regulation manifests into rigid response patterns that are crucial to the maintenance of this disorder. This proposal seeks to evaluate the interplay between negative emotion differentiation (NED), or the extent to which people discretely experience negative emotions, and self-reported avoidance and resting respiratory sinus arrythmia in PTSD using ambulatory assessment (i.e., ecological momentary assessment, ambulatory psychophysiology), and offers the potential to improve our understanding of how PTSD is developed and maintained over time.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection, causing infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and pelvic inflammatory disease in women. Despite the availability of effective treatment, the prevalence of chlamydia continues to rise, highlighting the need for a prophylactic vaccine. This proposal seeks to identify Chlamydia trachomatis vaccine candidates by investigating the functions of antibodies to specific epitopes of Chlamydia trachomatis proteins involved in binding and entering host cells, providing a novel approach for Chlamydia trachomatis vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some small cell lung cancers (SCLCs) are highly and selectively sensitive to inhibition of the histone demethylase LSD1, but the biological mechanisms utilized by LSD1 to drive SCLC are not well understood. This proposal seeks to understand the underlying causative mechanisms by which LSD1 drives SCLC tumorigenesis and neuroendocrine differentiation utilizing both cell lines and isogenic CRISPR-based in vivo mouse models. We will also test a rational combination therapeutic approach to overcome LSD1 inhibitor resistance, which if successful, could ultimately have a significant impact on treatment strategies for this recalcitrant cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Electronic biosensors are important for health diagnostics, disease prevention and treatment, although nonspecific charge interferences have prevented conventional biosensors from real-time detection in physiological environment. The proposed research intends to bring in and validate a new biosensor concept, which can be free of nonspecific interference and provide generic solution to the specific biodetection in physiological environment, potentially leading to advanced biomedical devices for point-of-care diagnostics. The sensor concept will be concreted by implementing it in the early detection of tick-borne diseases, which currently have imposed serious threat to public health but lacked timely diagnostics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Poor emotion recognition has been associated with poor quality of interpersonal relationships, loss of employment, behavioral problems, reduced social reintegration, social isolation and even suicide. Deficits in emotion recognition are common in traumatic brain injury (TBI) and in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) but these deficits have not been well studied in Veterans with both mild TBI (mTBI) and PTSD. Currently there are no interventions for emotion recognition in Veterans with mTBI and PTSD, and interventions for severe TBI have lacked training of both facial and vocal emotion recognition. In a preliminary study of an innovative combination of facial and vocal modalities, a multimodal affect recognition training (MMART) showed promise but lacked attention training that is an essential component in recognizing emotions in our daily lives. Given the need to improve relationships and productivity in Veterans with mTBI and PTSD, a study is needed to determine the effectiveness of a MMART combined with attention training.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Infection during pregnancy is known to increase the probability of offspring developing autism, yet the mechanism is not fully understood. Recently, we have found that fetal macrophages in the brain may secrete a pro-inflammatory molecule that we hypothesize could accelerate inflammation and disturb the proper development of neurons. This project aims to elucidate the mechanism of action of this pro-inflammatory molecule and determine whether its inhibition could be a new therapeutic strategy for treating autism induced by infection during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dismal outcomes of pancreatic cancer and its unresponsiveness to immunotherapy is, in part, due to the pro-tumorigenic, immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment engendered by infiltrating myeloid and fibroblastic cells. We have identified MerTK, Tyro3 and Axl receptor tyrosine kinases as important but distinct regulators of immunosuppressive myeloid cells and potentially cancer-associated fibroblasts. This research will elucidate mechanisms by which these kinases hinder the immune response and will evaluate novel, clinically applicable therapeutic agents that could magnify the response to current immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative / public health relevance statement Eye plaque brachytherapy has been an effective and established treatment for intraocular melanoma (the most common eye cancer in adults) and retinoblastoma (the most common eye cancer in children). Unlike the general trend in external beam radiotherapy, the advancement of plaque therapy lags behind in terms of intensity modulated delivery due to the limitation in the current capability of quality assurance. This project aims to develop a novel, easy-to-use, and low-cost device that allows fast and accurate quality assurance of loaded plaques, thereby ensuring the safety of patient treatment and facilitating the utilization of intensity modulation in plaque therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An explosion of recent studies has indicated that altered mechanical forces in a cell’s environment is a poten- tially targetable and quantifiable factor in disease, much like mutations in DNA or proteins, which makes intui- tive sense given that cancer is often diagnosed by detecting a lump that feels harder and stiffer than the sur- rounding tissue. Understanding how cell-surface proteins sense and respond to force will result in new therapeutic avenues and diagnostic tools for diseases like cancer, heart disease, muscular dystrophy, and polycystic kidney disease. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: As the population ages, the incident of non-healing ulcerative wounds dramatically increases, which is associated with increased mortality rates. Currently, the biochemical changes associated with both age and the non-healing wound pathologies are unknown. Herein, we will employ a multi-disciplinary team, novel pre-clinical models, and “state of the art” technologies coupled to a pertinent patient population to explore the underlying mechanisms and bioactive lipids associated with aging and non-healing wounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An expanding body of theory-driven research has consistently shown how factors related to sexual minority stigma, including structural, interpersonal, and intrapersonal factors, may drive sexual orientation-based mental health disparities. However, public health research has so far been unable to produce strong causal, longitudinal evidence on how structural forms of sexual minority stigma may jeopardize mental health outcomes among sexual minorities, including suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and depressive symptoms. The proposed secondary analysis of a large public health dataset (Add Health) will include advanced three- level multi-membership longitudinal models to examine three key aspects yet missing to facilitate causal inferencing regarding the mental health sequelae of structural sexual minority stigma exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a highly malignant skeletal muscle tumor, with frequent activation of the Ras signaling pathway, and poor outcomes for patients with relapsed or metastatic disease. We have identified that PAK4 as a key signaling node in RMS and will validate it as a new therapeutic target, in combination with chemotherapy or other targeted agents, for high-risk RMS. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the NIH's mission because understanding and validating new therapeutic targets for pediatric sarcomas will improve the treatment of such tumors while minimizing toxic effects of current therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper control of gene expression underlies all biological processes and importantly those involved in cellular differentiation and responses to external stresses. Accordingly, defects in core regulators of gene expression are the basis of many human diseases ranging from cancer to neurological disorders. We study how the mechanisms of gene expression are temporally coordinated such that cellular differentiation programs and responses to stress are executed in a timely and accurate manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PTSD can occur after a direct or indirect traumatic experience and is a highly prevalent and debilitating disorder. This research project adds uses two virtual reality paradigms specifically design to study threat and reward context discrimination within a single environment. In the long term, this research will shed light on deficits of specific brain areas and neural circuits during threat and reward learning and discrimination within an environment in PTSD, which will advance the development of effective diagnostics and treatments for PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance: The goal of this project is to develop and validate a method for the evaluation of bladder function. More specifically, we are proposing a new ultrasound-based method for detecting bladder detrusor muscle overactivity. This technique can also be used to monitor the bladder before and after a surgical procedure that is performed on men to treat enlarged prostate. Successful completion of this research will lead to a new diagnostic and monitoring tool for bladder patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The conformation and composition of massive molecular machines change as they are assembled and as they perform their essential cellular functions. Work proposed here will produce broadly impactful computational tools to determine the structures of these dynamic machines in motion. Such structures are critical in furthering our understanding of how these molecules function in healthy cells and how they fail in times of disease, and in guiding the development of therapeutics treating a wide array of human illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Human T follicular helper cells function by providing essential support to B cells in draining lymph nodes allowing those B cells to produce highly effective neutralizing antibodies following vaccination or infection. The dynamics of human antigen-specific T follicular helper cell development, maturation and function are not well-understood. The work we propose will fill this knowledge gap and lead to a deeper understanding of the impact of human T follicular helper cell maturation on function in the setting of a very efficacious human lipid nanoparticle mRNA vaccine platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood cells are produced in the bone marrow from hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), which maintain themselves through self-renewal, a process that must be tightly regulated in order to prevent a variety of bone marrow disorders. This application proposes to study a gene named PHF6, which regulates HSC self-renewal, and whose mutation can cause life-threatening bone marrow abnormalities. Understanding how PHF6 maintains self-renewal will help us understand how the balance of normal HSCs is maintained in health, and how an imbalance in this process can cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Heterochromatin is a conserved feature of eukaryotic chromosomes with roles in the regulation of gene expression and maintenance of genome stability, and contributes to normal development and disease progression in humans. A basic understanding of the mechanisms that mediate the assembly and epigenetic inheritance of heterochromatin will not only provide a frame work for understanding how the epigenetic regulatory mechanisms can fail, but also provides the substrate and knowledge to design therapeutic strategies based on intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We currently lack robust medical therapies for the cognitive and social / emotional symptoms caused by developmental brain disorders and neuropsychiatric diseases. To develop therapies, we must first understand the biology of the brain circuits that influence symptoms. In the proposed work, we will determine how specific populations of neurons in the thalamus process information, and how modulating the activity of those neurons influences cognitive, social, and affective behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poxviruses include past and present Category A Priority Pathogens and pandemic threats, while others are widely used as vaccine vectors and oncolytic therapies. Poxviruses are also highly unusual DNA viruses in that they are so self-sufficient that they replicate in the cytoplasm, yet they remain dependent on host ribosomes to synthesize viral proteins and replicate. This renewal application proposes to continue our ongoing research program aimed at understanding how poxviruses take control of host ribosomes in unusual ways, which is also providing unexpected insights into fundamental aspects of ribosome evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Development of a dual-iDDS probe multiplex test for detecting endemic fungal agents Confidential PI: Shafer, David A., PhD PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 500,000 such cases of Valley fever, histoplasmosis, or blastomycosis are thought to occur in the US annually, although only one FDA-approved molecular test exists for diagnosing Valley fever, and no FDA- approved molecular tests exist for diagnosing histoplasmosis or blastomycosis. Therefore, our long-term objective is to design and market a simple, lyophilized molecular test to assist in diagnosing these fungal agents, using our proprietary internal DNA-Detection Switch probe technology. Our Specific Aims are (1) to develop a 3- tube dual-iDDS probe assay for C. immitis, C. posadasii, H. capsulatum, and B. dermatitidis, and (2) to evaluate key performance characteristics of the multiplex test for endemic fungal agents in lyophilized format. Success in this endeavor should provide a clear public health benefit.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Encouraging safer storage of firearms among Veterans at risk for suicide is a top VA priority. While VA behavioral health providers routinely ask Veterans to store their firearms more safely during lethal means safety counseling (LMSC), only about half of individuals follow through on these recommendations. The proposed research capitalizes on VA’s experience delivering incentive-based interventions to develop an add- on intervention offering Veterans financial and/or social incentives to limit their access to firearms following LMSC. We will engage Veterans and VA clinicians and administrators throughout this process, and the add-on intervention will be pilot tested to assess its acceptability and feasibility. Included Veterans will be drawn from both urban and rural settings, and we will oversample Veterans who identify as women and racial/ethnic minorities. This proposal sets the stage for an IIR application to conduct a multi-site Hybrid Effectiveness- Implementation Type 1 Randomized Clinical Trial testing this add-on intervention.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Critical illness has a profound and lasting impact on patients and their families. The effects of critical illness may impair the physical, cognitive, and psychological recovery of Veterans who survive their ICU stay, as well as the family members who care for them. A growing evidence base demonstrates that family-centered ICU care—evidence-based practices that prioritize family members’ presence in the ICU, incorporate families as care partners, and elicit and respond to families’ values and needs—improves outcomes for patients, families, and clinicians. However, family-centered ICU care is not routinely delivered across U.S. hospitals, signifying that family-centered ICU care may be difficult to operationalize. There is an urgent need to eliminate barriers that prevent family-centered ICU care from being delivered consistently to critically ill Veterans and their families across VA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the leading cause of death in patients under 45, particularly prevalent in military service members and Veterans. Complementary and Integrative Health (CIH) approaches (e.g., Yoga and acupuncture) have been used to treat TBI symptoms, though little is known about the long-term outcomes associated with these treatments. We will analyze existing electronic health record data and conduct focus groups and interviews to provide the much-needed evidence to support the use CIH approaches in Veterans with TBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans, like other patient populations, often receive low-value health care services whose costs or harms exceed their benefits. Our work will address two key knowledge gaps on this topic. First, while low-value services are common, it is not clear why Veterans receive them. We will test whether the Choice/MISSION Act reforms, which increased Veterans’ access to non-VA clinicians, increased Veterans’ risk of receiving low- value services. Second, we lack high-quality evidence on what constitutes low-value care as well as what strategies are effective for translating evidence into clinical decision-making. We will investigate strategies to address low-value care via evidence development and evidence translation. Thus, our research will elucidate the causes of, and potential solutions to, low-value health care. This work directly aligns with the VA mission of ensuring high-value Veteran health care. It will provide VA with critical information to prioritize and implement policies with the goal of reducing low-value Veteran care in VA and non-VA settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Physical activity levels among Veterans who use wheelchairs is very low despite the importance of PA in improving overall physical and mental health. Wheelchair users face many barriers to exercise above that of the general population including lack of transportation to PA facilities and programs, social support, motivation and access to accessible fitness equipment and knowledgeable trainers. Home-based fitness products involving access to live and on-demand video instruction and virtual reality applications have become widely popular and beneficial for increasing fitness and motivation among able-bodied individuals during the pandemic however they are not accessible or tailored to the needs of wheelchair users. Therefore, the goal of this project is to develop a home-based upper arm exercise bike that will be compatible with video based instruction and virtual reality real-world riding apps that offer social components and motivational features.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA Community Care (CC) program has improved access to surgical care for Veterans unable to have treatment at VA Medical Centers. However, Veterans undergoing surgery outside the VA are at increased risk of chronic opioid use (COU). Transitional Pain Services (TPS) have been shown to reduce postoperative COU, but it is unknown whether this approach can be applied virtually to at-risk Veterans using CC for surgery. Through this project, we will generate important data to establish whether telehealth TPS can serve as an efficacious, scalable and cost-effective strategy to ensure safe opioid use among Veterans undergoing orthopedic surgery at non-VA hospitals. We will compare opioid use among Veterans using CC for orthopedic surgery randomized to telehealth TPS versus only standard care. We will interview VA providers and patients to identify barriers and facilitators to care coordination using TPS. Finally, we will conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis to compare whether telehealth TPS reduces COU without increasing costs to patients or VA payers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional MRI (fMRI) is the most widely-used tool to measure human brain function and has contributed enormously to human neuroscience, however fMRI does not measure neuron firing rather it detects brain activity by measuring changes in blood flow in the brain that delivers oxygen to the neurons. These changes in blood flow that occur in the smallest blood vessels near to the neurons provide more accurate information about which neurons are firing, whereas it is more difficult to know the location of neuron firing when observing changes blood flow within the largest vessels, yet standard fMRI methods mix together signal from large and small blood vessels. Here we seek to develop MRI technology that can enable the observation of blood flow changes exclusively from the smallest blood vessels, and we will use this to show that these changes are faster than those found in the largest blood vessels and so our technology can therefore be used to better track rapid changes in neuron firing.
