IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): In this R37 Extension application, we propose to define the roles played by the Plasmodium falciparum transporters PfCRT and PfMDR1 in mediating parasite resistance to antimalarial drugs currently used in firstline combination therapies. Our studies will explore risks posed by PfCRT mutations in negating antimalarial drug efficacy in Africa, define genetic associations between PfCRT and other genes that augment resistance or offset parasite fitness costs, identify compounds that could reverse mutant PfCRT-mediated drug efflux, and characterize structural and functional features of PfMDR1-mediated drug resistance. Results from this project will advance our understanding of P. falciparum drug action and multidrug resistance , and offer evidence-based strategies to reduce the impact of drug-resistant malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma patients benefit from several therapeutic options including immunomodulatory imide drugs (IMiDs), but most patients eventually acquire disease that is refractory to treatment and succumb to myeloma. This project will investigate the molecular targets of IMiDs – the transcription factors IKAROS and AIOLOS – to determine their function and role in IMiD resistance. Results will inform the mechanisms by which IMiDs function or fail to function in myeloma, where IMiD-resistance is a major driver of mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A fundamental capacity of the primate visual system is its ability to track dynamic visual stimuli. To understand how this is achieved, we will conduct a combination of primate neurophysiological and behavioral studies using novel, custom-designed visual stimuli to investigate how area V4, an intermediate stage of cortical visual processing, integrates visual information across space and time. The proposed experiments will provide deeper understanding of cortical representations, particularly the neuronal basis of global motion perception and the tracking of dynamic objects—processes that are impaired in aging populations, especially those with Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This project aims to unravel the molecular mechanisms that control dendrite development in the nervous system. We will also investigate dendritic function (especially mechano-sensation) and dendrite regeneration, research topics that extend our interest in dendrites. Given that dendrite defects are the likely cause of many neurological and mental disorders such as autism and Down syndrome, this project could contribute to the diagnosis and possible treatment in the future.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The VA Opioid Safety Initiative has reduced high-risk opioid prescribing and improved pain treatments for Veterans in VA care. To enhance access and improve health outcomes for Veterans, the MISSION Act expanded eligibility criteria for VA purchased services provided by non-VA community clinics (VA Community Care [CC]). VA is still charged with ensuring high-quality care for Veterans receiving CC services, including for outpatient treatment of pain. It is unclear how CC expansion has impacted opioid safety and patient-reported outcomes for Veterans receiving CC-prescribed opioids, particularly given known challenges in care coordination and health care communication for CC services. The proposed project will examine factors associated with receiving CC- prescribed opioids, and evaluate outcomes for Veterans who receive any opioids CC-prescribed opioids vs. only VA-prescribed opioids. These results are essential for developing future strategies to better integrate VA and non-VA provided services, and improving outcomes for Veterans receiving CC services for pain treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Evidence suggests that VA cancer quality has rivaled that provided in the community, but how the MISSION Act has affected cancer care quality remains unknown. The current study will produce the following: 1) a set of cancer quality measures appropriate for tracking cancer quality in VA and the community; 2) a report of cancer care quality across VA-delivered and VA-purchased community care since the institution of MISSION, including an evaluation of the role of care fragmentation and other system and patient-level factors on quality; and 3) an assessment of quality in cancer providers in the community who contract with VA as compared to geographically proximate providers who do not. This study will lay the foundation for an appropriately flexible and robust measurement system that will allow both policy makers and researchers to learn how to improve cancer quality for Veterans in the decades to come. For Veterans, the study will yield critical information that can help them decide whether and when to receive VA-delivered vs VA-purchased community care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Thoracic malignancies are the principal source of cancer related deaths due to the rapid metastatic spread of lung cancer cells to the brain. Our novel multi- disciplinary approach proposes to reveal drug targetable molecules that are specific to certain tissue cell types and which characterize this aggressive clinical course. We believe that this project will reveal fundamental new principles in gene regulation, pulmonary and brain biology, neuro-inflammation, as well as provide more tailored therapeutic insight for lung cancer patients at risk of metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity afflicts approximately 42% of the adults in the United States and obese patients are at increased risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a final pathway of acute lung injury from infectious or sterile etiologies with high mortality. We have found evidence that increased acute lung injury in high fat diet induced obesity is linked to elevated free fatty acids in the lung with associated alterations in fatty acid oxidation, de novo fatty acid synthesis and mitochondrial fusion enzymes. In this proposal, we aim to uncover a link between dysregulated fatty acid metabolism, mitochondrial dysfunction and increased susceptibility to acute lung injury in obesity, with the ultimate goal of supporting the development of therapies for obese patients at risk of ARDS based on targeting lipid metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although intense research has focused on the neurodevelopmental consequences of prenatal ZIKV infection, less is known about postnatal infection in early life, when significant growth and maturation of the brain occurs. Here we will use a nonhuman primate model of postnatal ZIKV exposure to interrogate the specific long-term neurobehavioral impact of ZIKV infection at different stages of infant postnatal brain development. Increased understanding of the full spectrum of disease caused by ZIKV in infants and children will allow us to be better prepared to respond in the likely event of future ZIKV outbreaks.

PHR: Project narrative: We propose to evaluate GPC3-CAR T cells co-expressing IL15 alone or both IL15 and IL21 to determine their safety, expansion, persistence, and antitumor activity against GPC3+ tumors, which collectively represent the largest group of extracranial pediatric solid cancers. In addition, we will define evolving immune escape mechanisms employed by tumor cells following CAR T cell treatment at the single cell resolution. Results from these studies may serve as blueprint for effective countermeasures to enhance our CAR T cell treatment and others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Human guanylate kinase (hGMPK) is an essential enzyme in the production of DNA and RNA making it a potential therapeutic target for cancer and SARS-CoV-2. We have shown that active site distant mutations arising from non-synonymous single nucleotide variants of hGMPK enhance enzymatic catalysis, without a perceptible change in the kinase’s backbone structure, an apparent contradiction to the structure-function paradigm. This proposal investigates what is responsible for this catalytic enhancement from a rigorous kinetic and thermodynamic perspective, the results of which will impact future approaches toward drug discovery and biomolecular regulation through the direct linkage of enzymatic function to the conformational landscape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The expertise provided by the SDMC will help advance research concerning the treatment of adults living with HIV and co-infections such as tuberculosis and hepatitis B virus. It will achieve this by ensuring that ACTG clinical trials and other studies are designed, conducted, and analyzed efficiently and to the highest standards using state-of-the-art, compliant clinical and laboratory information management systems that ensure complete and high-quality data. This research will continue to make significant contributions in advancing optimal treatment of people living with HIV both in the United States and internationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: BDNF is the most well-studied neurotrophic factor in the central nervous system and its role in maturation and synapse development in neurons is well characterized. To date, no study has evaluated a role for BDNF in the development or morphological maturation in a non-neuronal cell type, even though astrocytes express the highest levels of the receptor for BDNF, TrkB. Successful completion of these studies have the potential to advance our understanding of a novel molecular signaling that serves to recruit astrocytes perisynaptic processes to glutamatergic synapses. These studies lay the groundwork for novel inquiries into aberrant BDNF/TrkB signaling in a growing list of neurodevelopmental and neurological disorders whereby BDNF and astrocytes are increasingly implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a high-risk factor for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), a common and serious public health problem that currently lacks effective therapies. High levels of transforming growth factor- beta 1 (TGFβ1) are present in both humans and mice with diabetes and NASH. We propose to use state-of- the-art genomic tools and genetic and disease models to investigate the mechanisms of action and therapeutic potential of targeting TGFβ1 signaling in treating T2D and metabolic liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The perception of motion is critical for normal human vision yet the cells, circuits and mechanisms that give rise to selectivity for movement direction have never been identified in the primate retina. The proposed project arises from the discovery of direction selective ganglion cells and associated novel circuitry in the macaque monkey retina and applies state of the art connectomic and functional imaging methods to advance understanding of the primate direction selective circuit for the first time. Outcomes will have significance for advancing understanding of motion processing in human vision and impact on the development of tools for cellular imaging and vision restoration in the unique primate retinal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ideal antibacterial and hemocompatible surface would prevent bacterial biofilm formation as well as platelet adhesion and activation. This research project will develop and evaluate the synergistic effects of S-nitrosothiol based nitric oxide (NO) release along with a surface immobilized catalytic heparin moiety that can extend the therapeutic levels of nitric oxide for longer periods. These materials will be studied for their prevention of platelet activation/adhesion, fibrin formation, and microbial infection, thereby solving major clinical problems of thrombosis and infection associated with long-term intravascular catheter devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The foods and beverages people shop for and store in their homes are related to the foods they consume and the development of diet-related diseases such as obesity, cancer, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Research to address health disparities in diet-related disease is critical but often stymied by the lack of measurement tools that are specific, appropriate, and valid for diverse populations such as Latinos. The proposed research will develop and make available a toolkit of valid home food inventories to use in diet- related health research to reduce health disparities among Latino and low-literacy populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of all cancer-related deaths in the U.S and worldwide. High YEATS2 expression is associated with worse prognosis of several types of cancers including non-small cell lung cancer, indicating that YEATS2 is a potential drug target. The objective of this proposal is to develop potent and specific inhibitors to target the histone acylation binding activity of the YEATS2 YEATS domain that will provide the basis for further development of small molecules for targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer deaths in the United States for men and women combined, and approximately 40% of patients with this disease will eventually die of tumor metastasis. This proposal aims to deepen our understanding of signaling pathways and immune evasion mechanisms in metastatic colorectal cancer by taking a novel approach for investigating mTOR signaling biology and its deregulation in the molecular pathogenesis of this invasive disease, with the goal of identifying selective translational regulators as novel cancer therapeutic targets. This knowledge is expected to lay a foundation for the development of novel therapies for metastatic colorectal cancer, a goal with clear and significant implications for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Relevance In acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the advent of effective targeted therapies, intensiﬁed chemotherapy, and allo- geneic stem cell transplant have increased long-term survival such that a non-negligible subset of treated patients are cured; when cured subjects are present in a dataset, mixture cure models should be used in place of tra- ditional survival analytic techniques. We will develop novel methodologies and software for ﬁtting mixture cure models that accommodate modeling a high-dimensional feature space to enable researchers to identify molec- ular features from high-throughput genomic assays that are associated with likelihood of cure and time-to-event outcomes. Application of our methods will enhance existing AML risk stratiﬁcation systems used in daily clinical practice that determine treatment intensity and modality, identify potential therapeutic targets, and will be broadly applicable to the large number of genomic studies housed in NCBI's GEO portal that involve time-to-event analy- ses and a cured fraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancers driven by the oncogene KRAS are responsible for more than 70,000 deaths in the United States annually. Recently developed small molecules directly targeting the KRASG12C mutation have produced high response rates in patients with lung cancer, but only show limited benefit for patients with colorectal cancer. In this proposal, we study the signaling links between KRAS and the transcription factor CTNNB1 to understand the mechanisms of resistance to KRAS inhibition in colorectal cancer and find new therapeutic combinations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Program Narrative To understand pathogenic mechanisms of frontotemporal dementia and related disorders, we will use a combination of genetic, molecular and cellular approaches in mouse and Drosophila models as well as induced pluripotent stem cell models to perform a series of experiments. The proposed mechanistic studies will contribute to the development of therapeutic avenues for these insidious disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application to RFA-AI-19-002 is to continue as the statistical and data management center (SDMC) for the HIV Prevention Trials Network, which plans to 1) conduct a program of Phase 1-3 trials for testing new agents (antiretrovirals, broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies and multi-purpose technologies) for the prevention of HIV infection and 2) evaluate integrated strategy interventions that optimize use of proven efficacious prevention interventions tailored to specific populations at risk. The HPTN SDMC has faculty biostatisticians experienced in the design, conduct and analysis of global HIV prevention studies, who support the goals of HPTN research through leadership in statistical design, trial conduct and analysis, and development and implementation of innovative statistical methods as needed and motivated by HPTN scientific goals. The SDMC provides regulatory compliant data management functions for all HPTN trials, including electronic data capture directly from research sites, integration of laboratory specimens and assay results, and electronic participant reported outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Pulmonary fibrosis (PF) is a rare degenerative disease characterized by progressive lung stiffening, and punctuated by intermittent inflammatory episodes of unknown cause, termed “acute exacerbations”. Both genetic and environmental triggers are linked to disease pathogenesis and progression. Mutations of the epithelial cell-specific gene encoding for the surfactant protein-C (SP-C) are linked to clinical PF. To longitudinally examine endpoints relevant to PF, we developed a novel murine model that leverages the most common human mutation in the SP-C gene. The ubiquitous air pollutant ozone (O3) represents a major environmental contributor to disease exacerbation in vulnerable populations, including PF. Monocytes and macrophages are centrally involved in ozone toxicity and represent a predictor in PF severity. This project aims to functionally link monocyte/macrophage populations as central players in the exacerbation of PF resulting from ozone exposure of the SP-C mutant mice. Ultimately, we hope to identify a unique subset of monocyte- derived cells responsible for tissue damage, and thus develop a cell specific approach to improve health of PF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elevated insulin levels and low-grade inflammation are associated with insulin resistance, a hallmark of diet induced obesity, though little is known about how insulin and cellular insulin resistance influences immune cell function. Here, we show that insulin signaling in B cells of the immune system has critical effects on these cells’ functional capacity and inflammatory responses. Our proposed studies aim to better understand how insulin and its receptor impact B cells in health and during obesity related insulin resistance through study of the immunology and metabolism of B cell specific insulin receptor knock out mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major public health issue, especially among children and adolescents, but current neuroimaging research tools have limited utility in this population due to unique issues related to development and TBI-related focal injury. Using multi-site data, we propose to develop a toolbox that addresses key limitations –– specifically, proper accounting of lesions and the use of age-appropriate templates –– and use that toolbox to identify factors associated with harmonized outcome measures. Our novel, comprehensive, cost-effective, easy-to-use, and well-supported workflow will lead to patient-specific profiles of pathology that are sensitive to patient heterogeneity and simultaneously allow for multi-site, harmonized analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Histones are the main protein constituent of chromatin, the physiological relevant form of the genome, and function to compact the large eukaryotic genomes and regulate DNA-based processes such as gene expression. However, we have discovered that histones also functions as an enzyme to generate copper ions that can be used by the cell for many important processes and functions. We propose to investigate this novel role of histones in regulation of copper biology inside the cell that has important consequences for basic understanding of eukaryotic biology as well as human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite extensive studies on relationships between diets and cancer risk, or many “balanced” nutrition therapies with hope to keep cancer patients healthy and strong for treatment and recovery, little is known about how dietary substances influence cancer and anti-cancer therapies. We thus constructed a “blood chemical (BC)” compound library, which contains circulating diet-derived nutrients including inorganics, organic metabolites, lipids, and dietary supplements, and performed screens to identify BCs that influence responses to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs). In this proposal, we hypothesize that dietary trans-vaccenic acid (TVA), the predominant form of trans fatty acids in human milk, enhances activation of CD8+ T cells and consequent anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving the implementation of suicide prevention practices in juvenile detention centers, centers that disproportionately serve African American and Black youth, may allow for earlier identification of youth at risk for suicide and the prevention of suicidal behaviors. The mentorship, training, and research activities proposed will result in a feasible, acceptable, and appropriate model of suicide prevention within juvenile detention centers. Developing independent investigators with the knowledge and skills to conduct this type of work is particularly important given that suicide prevention is a national priority, especially as it relates to juvenile justice-involved youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Diabetes management in patients with ESRD represent a challenge for clinicians and patients. These patients are exposed to wide glycemic exposures, and high risk for hypoglycemia and glycemic variability. Current glucose control measures lack accuracy and validation in ESRD patients. Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) provides a comprehensive, real-time 24-hours glucose profile, but no prior study has included ESRD patients. The proposed research intends to fill this critical knowledge gap by testing a new strategy with novel factory-calibrated CGMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Swallowing disorders are directly linked to aging and contribute to multiple other health care problems potentially affecting more than 70 million aging Americans. The proposed Dysphagia: In Search of a Unified Definition for the Aging Population conference will bring together expert scientists, researchers, and stakeholders in the arena of dysphagia and aging to formally synthesize, discuss, and agree upon an accepted definition for dysphagia across the domains of screening, diagnosis, treatment, management and ongoing care. Requested funding from this R13 award will support attendance of discussants in aging and dysphagia, stakeholders, under-represented junior and minority scientists, and support associated conference service costs, leading to uniformity in the definition of dysphagia for academics, research, public policy, and health care landscape to improve the care of the aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose novel methods and algorithms to develop personalized dynamic risk prediction and to identify modifiable risk factors for kidney stone progression. The proposed methods will be evaluated and validated with multiple real-world datasets from kidney stone research consortia. The success of this project will fill the knowledge gap of kidney stone disease progression, and lead to a predictive toolbox to inform clinicians on the risk of stone disease progression, thereby facilitating timely clinical decision-making and effective implementation of targeted strategies to prevent or reduce stone disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The experience of daily stressors can accelerate cognitive decline and increase the risk of heart disease, depression, and other debilitating chronic illnesses – especially for those who are in underrepresented minority groups or live in low-income areas. In this project, we measure the daily stressors of mid-life (aged 50-64) adults using mobile phones, which allows us to better understand where and how stressors happen as people go about their daily lives. This knowledge can be used to develop community or psychological interventions to address environmental stressors and promote healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We recently discovered that mice with hyperactive stress circuits exhibit an increased incidence of SUDEP. Given that both stress and SUDEP link to disruption of central circuits responsible for the regulation of cardiorespiratory function, this application will interrogate a potential, novel pathophysiological mechanisms contributing to SUDEP involving hyperactive stress circuits and exaggerated cardiac vagal output. This application has the potential to uncover a novel mechanism contributing to SUDEP risk, which may also be relevant to other forms of sudden death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Kidney disorders including acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal diseases (ESRD) are prevalent in sickle cell disease (SCD) and account for significant morbidity and mortality in this patient population. Incidences of AKI, compelling risk factors for CKD and ESRD, are major clinical concerns among SCD patients hospitalized for acute hemolytic crisis. Enhanced clearance of excess circulating heme to the kidneys during hemolysis promotes clinically relevant AKI in murine model of SCD. The role of altered heme scavenging system, clearing free circulating heme, in the pathogenesis of AKI is unknown. This project will determine i) the association of two heme scavengers, hemopexin and alpha-1-microglobulin, with AKI in SCD patients, ii) the mechanism by which heme regulates the biosynthesis of heme scavengers, and iii) the putative pathway that impairs heme degradation by heme oxygensase-1 in SCD kidneys. This proposal will determine if ratio of plasma heme scavengers’ concentration serves as a prognostic risk factor for AKI in SCD. The results of this proposal will also identify specific intermediate therapeutic targets to block AKI pathogenesis in order to improve adverse outcomes of kidney injuries in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunosuppressive myeloid cells are recognized as a significant barrier to the efficacy of immunotherapies in cancer patients although their precise site of action is not fully understood. Our laboratory discovered that myeloid cells interact with anticancer immune cells directly within the blood, forming previously unrecognized ‘circulating myeloid cell (CMC) clusters’ that we propose instigate global immune suppression. Our proposed research has the potential to define CMC clusters as a novel mechanism of immune suppression, thereby implicating these cellular conjugates as a blood-based biomarker to guide treatment decisions to improve patient responses to anticancer agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative We hypothesize that the period of convalescence after TBI is caused by the loss of the capacity of brain cells to metabolize the energy necessary to sustain brain plasticity and function. We will determine the capacity of a natural BDNF agonist to restore energy balance with subsequent enhancement of physical rehabilitation outcome after concussive brain injury. We will combine functional brain imaging, molecular assessments of synaptic plasticity and metabolism, and behavior to assess the efficacy of the interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food pantries face many challenges, including recruitment and training of staff/volunteers, communications with staff/volunteers and clients, providing client choice, and emergency preparedness. We will develop, implement, and evaluate the Support Application for Food Pantries (SAFPAS), a mobile application to address these concerns under normal and emergency operations, and assess its impact on 20 Baltimore food pantries, and on the healthiness of foods received by 360 food pantry clients using a randomized controlled trial design. If successful, the tested and refined app will support local food assistance programs throughout the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Annually, over 356,000 Americans have cardia arrest at outside of hospitals, and emergency medical services (EMS) provides crucial care such as airway management and medication administration. This proposal will identify the optimal timing of the resuscitation interventions at EMS systems that impacts survival after out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to validate potential targets for chemoradiation sensitization in patients with cervical cancer undergoing chemoradiation for cure. This will be accomplished by testing previously identified potential targets in cervical cancer cell lines and organoid models and by computationally validating mutations that expand during CRT in patients undergoing treatment. This proposal uses a novel, non-invasive swab-based biopsy method to collect serial data without harm or discomfort to patients, which is the first approach in cervical cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to arsenic early in life results in the loss of key gut microbiota that tune local and systemic immunity. Here, we propose to use a combination of human-focused studies, molecular studies with lab cell models, and animal work to understand how the arsenic-mediated loss of Bacteroides impacts immunity and health outcomes, and how arsenic-mediated effects can be mitigated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative b-lactamases are enzymes that hydrolyze b-lactam antibiotics to provide bacterial drug resistance and the emergence of b-lactamases that are capable of hydrolyzing virtually all b-lactam antibiotics is a significant threat to the efficacy of antibiotic therapy. The proposed experiments utilize enzyme kinetics, X-ray crystallography and molecular dynamics simulations is to provide a quantitative understanding of how b- lactam antibiotics traverse the catalytic pathway of KPC b-lactamases, yielding insights necessary for the rational design of molecules that act are poorly hydrolyzed as well as inhibitors of these enzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will inform our understanding of how to support emerging adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). We will use a theoretically informed and research-based transition support program developed for people with ASD and test how effective it is when delivered by community agencies. Results will provide information on the effectiveness of the program as well as on mechanisms of change and contextual factors that promote or impede implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, we will examine how the retina and the gut communicate and how this communication is altered by the presence of type 2 diabetes. We will study how the loss of a critical protein, angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), in diabetes disturbs glucose absorption and the release of gut hormones that regulate blood glucose levels. Finally, we test how loss of ACE2 influences gut barrier function to impact systemic inflammation and progression of diabetic retinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We identified a striking CD4 T cell population in the human gut that expressed high levels of cytotoxic mediators following exposure to enteric bacteria. Understanding the biology of these human gut cytotoxic CD4 T cells may inform strategies to curb mucosal HIV-1 replication, CD4 T cell death and HIV-1-associated immune activation and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Timing and temporal coding is important aspect of many brain systems and the underlying mechanisms play a role in numerous neurological disorders including dyslexia and autism. The cerebellum currently represents the best opportunity to brain understand mechanisms of timing. A better understanding of these processes could open doors for innovative treatment strategies for a variety of disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We propose to develop a machine learning-based biomechanical analysis approach for rupture risk assessment of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA). This study will lead to a breakthrough in the fields of cardiovascular computational modeling and applied machine learning, provide new insights on how to better assess TAA risk, and reduce death by the silent and sudden killer of TAA disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Fatty liver disease occurs in about 25% in the general population of the United States and as high as 70% in the obese population and those with Diabetes; and in individual who consume alcohol. With the increase in obesity rate and continued excessive drinking behavior in the US population, fatty liver is in line to become the leading cause of liver transplantation in the next 10 years. This project will study the molecular changes occurring with fatty liver using mouse models. We also designed an inhibitor to block the signal that we have discovered. We expect this inhibitor to exhibit therapeutic effect at treating fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Alpha herpesviruses, like herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), naturally infect the peripheral nervous system causing recurrent herpetic lesions, and can spread to the central nervous system causing encephalitis or may contribute to neurodegenerative disease. To spread to and within the nervous system, alpha herpesvirus particles must transport inside and then exit from infected cells, either non-neuronal cells, or neurons. The goal of this research is to better understand how HSV-1 spreads in the nervous system by investigating the molecular and cell biology of these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA is constantly damaged in cells and must be repaired to maintain cellular health. This application examines protein complexes that form during a DNA repair process called uracil base excision repair. Uracil base excision repair regulates several biological processes including adaptive immunity, the infectivity of certain viruses, and the efficacy of specific chemotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurological disease impacts the health of nearly 100 million Americans yearly, making it essential to increase our understanding of how neurons achieve their proper shape and function. Many neurodevelopmental and degenerative diseases arise from perturbing the microtubule cytoskeleton. Through our studies, we will gain new insight into mechanisms that regulate the balance of stable and dynamic microtubules at synapses; in the future, this knowledge may be leveraged to advance innovative treatments of diseases associated with microtubule dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep apnea impacts up to 4% of adults and is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, stroke, diabetes, and cancer. The goal of this project is to determine how chronic intermittent hypoxia, a feature of sleep apnea, impacts the bone marrow of patients with the blood cancer multiple myeloma. The results from the studies proposed here will provide critical information that may be used to develop clinical trials aimed at improving outcomes for patients with this incurable cancer and will lay the groundwork for future studies in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression is a recurrent illness and even with successful antidepressant treatment, older adults with late-life depression are at high risk of recurrence. However, neurobiological processes that contribute to vulnerability to recurrence are poorly understood, limiting our ability to target mechanisms in prevention studies. The current study will elucidate neurobiological contributors to recurrence, examine the interrelationship between recurrence and cognitive decline, and provide data on the predictive utility of clinical monitoring in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Sustained activation of the innate immune system during periods of rapid growth leads to growth failure, whether in children suffering from chronic enteropathogen infection or in the model organism Drosophila melanogaster. In young children and in fruit fly larvae, innate immune signaling leads to insufficient circulating levels of homologous growth-promoting hormones: liver-derived insulin-like growth factor-1 and fat body-derived Drosophila insulin-like peptide 6. How infection impairs the endocrine control of growth is poorly understood, and the studies proposed here will use genetic approaches in flies and mammals to identify molecular mechanisms that link innate immune signaling with disrupted endocrine function and growth impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the U.S., youth ages 15-24 years comprise only 13% of the U.S. population, but represent 21% of incident HIV and approximately 50% of incident STI cases, underscoring the critical need for innovative research to address these co-occurring epidemics. Conducting the proposed research within the structure of a mentored, career development framework, with focused training in behavioral intervention adaptation and development, implementation science, and clinical and pragmatic trial design and management will help establish my career as an independent clinician-scientist dedicated to HIV and STI prevention in adolescents and young adults. The program of applied research and associated training delineated in this award will focus on the adaptation (Aim 1), implementation optimization (Aim 2), and testing (Aim 3) of a PrEP-inclusive health coaching intervention to reduce HIV and STI incidence among adolescents and young adults, which aims to be scalable across primary care contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells are addicted to glucose but only to secrete the majority as lactate (also known as aerobic glycolysis or Warburg effect), thereby creating an inhospitable glucose-poor and lactate-rich microenvironment that would otherwise be lethal to most cells. This application is designed to mechanistically investigate how lactate regulates cancer cell glucose utilization and to assess the therapeutic potential of targeting cancer lactate oxidation. The results from this study will provide knowledge in the regulation of central carbon metabolism and insight into the targeting lactate oxidation as a cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disease with devastating personal, familial, societal and economic burdens for which there is currently no effective means of prevention or treatment. In this proposal, we will use genetic analyses to systematically infer causal relationships between health, lifestyle, psychosocial, disease and molecular (gene expression, protein levels, metabolites) traits for Alzheimer’s disease outcomes. Completion of this proposal has the potential to identify novel causes of Alzheimer’s disease that have not been previously captured using traditional epidemiological approaches and to prioritize factors for immediate intervention to reduce risk now.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE Center-based programs to promote regular physical activity among patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) are frequently not available and when offered are associated with significant barriers for patients. Home based programs may improve access to these effective programs among Veterans. However, which delivery methods are most effective is not known. This study will use a SMART design to compare two delivery methods for a home-based walking program tailored to Veterans with PAD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative  Traumatic brain injury leaves Veterans with persistent neurological symptoms, specifically cognitive impairments, that require treatment of the chronic injured brain. Using an experimental model of spatial navigation cognitive rehabilitation, cognitive function is preserved in diffuse brain-injured rats when administered early after injury. Efficacy is lost when treatment is delayed, as would be necessary for Veterans. In preliminary results, psychoplastogens – drugs that induce neuroplasticity – preceding cognitive rehabilitation rescue cognitive function in the chronic period of TBI. The proposed research investigates psychoplastogen drug concentrations that induce a neuroplastic state, demonstrate the therapeutic efficacy of drug treatment preceding rehabilitation, and quantify the neuroplastic changes in cells, synapses, and receptors. The proposed research is relevant to the VA mission, because the results would provide evidence for effective treatment strategies for chronic cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Statins are the most cost-effective medications to lower cholesterol and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk. However, many patients at high-risk for CVD do not accept or adhere to statins. This gap in patient’s use of statins limits the full impact of these effective medications resulting in higher cholesterol levels and CVD risk. The main barriers to using statins are patients’ perceived lack of benefit, excess risk of statin toxicity as well as their misperceptions of their CVD risk. Statin pharmacogenomic testing – an application of precision medicine – is a readily available, feasible, and inexpensive intervention that addresses this barrier by using genetic testing to identify the nearly 1 out of 2 patients with enhanced benefit and/or reduced risk of statin toxicity or increased risk for CVD. By communicating statin pharmacogenomic test results to Veterans at high- risk for CVD not taking statin therapy, we aim to improve patients’ perceptions of their risk of CVD and statins and, in turn, their acceptance of and adherence to statins to reduce their cholesterol levels and CVD risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA WESTERN NEW YORK HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), also known as concussion, is a common injury sustained by Veterans. While most individuals who sustain mTBI experience a complete recovery within several weeks of injury, many Veterans with history of mTBI report frequent and long-lasting neurobehavioral complaints and functional impairment. Though research suggests that these outcomes are strongly influenced by co-occurring conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and chronic pain, evidence-based interventions capable of addressing this wide array of concerns are lacking. This study seeks to address this gap by evaluating the effectiveness of a brief and flexible behavioral health treatment (Problem-Solving Training for Concussion, or PST-Concussion), which was designed to be delivered by generalist providers working in VA primary care settings. If PST-Concussion is shown to be effective, this skills-focused intervention may help improve Veterans’ recovery experience following mTBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Studies in animal models show that the antiretroviral medications used to manage or prevent HIV can harm hearing and magnify the risk of ototoxic hearing loss by damaging mitochondrial DNA. Yet there has been no investigation of the impact of these drugs on human hearing. This proposed research is relevant to Veterans’ health because it will clarify the genetic and auditory effects of antiretroviral exposure on Veterans receiving healthcare from the Veterans Health Administration (VA), the largest single provider of HIV care in the United States. Continued use of daily antiretroviral therapy is a cornerstone of VA’s strategies for HIV prevention and management and the US Department of Health and Human Service’s goal to end the HIV epidemic by 2030. Once regimens with the greatest risk of ototoxicity and genotoxicity have been identified, alternative regimens for HIV management and prevention can be implemented that support these public health goals while preserving hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain prioritizes information processing to the most pressing stimuli at a given time. The barn owl, a specialist in sound localization studied for several decades, has a well-described circuit dedicated to identifying and localizing the most salient sounds in the environment. Previous study has shown that this circuit utilizes gamma oscillations in space coding. This unique circuit provides the opportunity to assess the role of oscillations in encoding perception of salient sounds in circumstances of many competing sounds, which may have future implications for understanding potential bases of deficits in stimulus detection in noisy environments caused by hearing loss and the optimization of hearing aids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vector control is the primary tool to prevent vector-borne diseases such as dengue, Zika and malaria. This project aims to study the sex determinate and sexually dimorphic genes in the dengue vector, Aedes aegypti to develop new genetic vector control technologies to suppress disease vector populations. These resulting technologies will provide insight into the biology of this important vector and may lead to the development of a more cost effective and efficacious strategy to prevent vector-borne disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alcohol related hospitalizations have been on the rise throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and intestinal barrier function has been shown to play a key role in the development of alcohol induced liver injury. Our proposed studies will reveal a very new cell-type specific mechanism by which intestinal epithelial and immune cells cross-talk in terms of signaling of a very important protein called Aryl Hydrocarbon Receptor (AhR) to restore the damage caused by alcohol on the gut and the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project aims to uncover specific host factors and responses that contribute to viral tropism and patterns of neuroinflammation. Through a combination of whole mount and single molecule imaging, sequencing, and classical virology exploiting both murine and human models, the immune reaction to flaviviral encephalitis will be profiled at the single cell level and interrogated as to how it is modulated by autocrine, paracrine, and endocrine immune signaling. This will shed light on the pathogenesis of encephalitic flaviviruses and serve as a blueprint for understanding neuroinflammation for a variety of non- viral CNS conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a common blinding disease characterized by biochemical changes and atrophy of the blood vessels that supply the retina. Understanding how genes contribute to the dysfunction of these blood vessels will enable the creation of better treatments for AMD. In this research program we will study how an important gene affects the behavior of human blood vessel cells and will identify additional genes that distinguish between early AMD, “dry” AMD and “wet” AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to clarify how certain genes act to cause a form of uveitis (inflammation within the eye) which is common in many parts of the world as well as in Americans of Hispanic, East Asian, Middle Eastern and South European descent: Behcet's Eye Disease (BED). This form of uveitis often leads to blindness if not treated, and current treatments can fail or cause serious side effects. Successful completion of this project will help design better medications for BED and similar diseases which pose large public health problems such as psoriasis, certain types of arthritis and bowel inflammation as well as other forms of uveitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  During infancy and throughout the first years of life, touch powerfully contributes to infant-parent interactions that are fundamental for social development. Abnormalities in tactile perception are prevalent features in individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD), exacerbating core social communication deficits. Understanding the circuit mechanisms through which early somatosensory neuronal networks are modulated for social significance will provide crucial information on the establishment of attachment, as well as a framework that can help refine therapeutic directions and intervention efforts for treating symptoms of ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is a common cause of enterically-transmitted viral hepatitis globally that has re-emerged in recent years within the United States causing multiple disease outbreaks and >140 deaths. This project investigates the crucial role played by distinct host lipid species in the HAV lifecycle, and how these lipids contribute to the ability of the virus to enter and infect cells and to produce new infectious progeny virus released from cells cloaked in host membranes. The proposed research addresses a neglected facet of the biology of this important human pathogen, and may suggest novel approaches to treatment and prevention of infections by this and other viruses with similar lifecycles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) are a leading cause of maternal mortality and morbidity, particularly for Black women who are at greatest risk of poor outcomes. Neighborhood greenspace has been associated with improved cardiovascular (CV) outcomes in the general population, but few studies have evaluated the relationship between greenspace and the development of HDP and chronic hypertension (cHTN) after pregnancy. The objective of this proposal is to leverage both an observational and experimental study design to evaluate the impact of neighborhood greenspace and a greenspace intervention on HDP and cHTN in a cohort of 92,000 pregnant patients, as well as to quantify the extent to which greenspace contributes to Black-white HDP and cHTN disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite nutritional interventions and attempts to improve sanitation, undernutrition remains a pressing global health problem that persists across generations. Environmental enteric dysfunction (EED) is a small intestinal inflammatory enteropathy that has been postulated to contribute to the pathogenesis of undernutrition in children and its poor long-term outcomes; however, the etiology of EED is poorly understood. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the hypothesis that a perturbed small intestinal microbiota contributes to the pathophysiology of EED in children and in women of reproductive age by integrating gnotobiotic mouse models and multi-omic technologies in order to identify microbial targets and ultimately develop therapies towards undernutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), rheumatoid arthritis, and venous, pressure, and diabetic ulcers are associated with excessive numbers of white blood cells called neutrophils entering a tissue. Being able to repel neutrophils from a tissue, and/or augment the effect of a neutrophil repellent, could be useful as a therapeutic. Relatively little is known about cell repellents, and we propose to study these mechanisms using the advantages of a simple model system, and then use this information to help develop therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is an increasingly prevalent condition effecting about 30% of Americans and costing the U.S about $103 billion per year, with no FDA approved treatments beyond lifestyle alterations. Mammalian target of rapamycin complex 2 (mTORC2) is emerging as a major metabolic hub and its activation has been linked to NAFLD in mice due to its role in regulating lipid metabolism in response to high fat diets, however, the major dietary supplements attributed to NAFLD prevalence are carbohydrates, especially fructose. In this proposal, I will investigate the role of hepatic mTORC2 in regulating carbohydrate derived acetyl-CoA production and utilization in NAFLD, using a combination of molecular biology, metabolomic, and proteomic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increased DNA damage and DNA damage response (DDR) activation is well-documented in cardiovascular disease (CVD) and heart failure in humans, but no current treatment strategies exist to target this population. Here, applying cutting-edge optical, biological, and bioelectrical tools we will map cardiac tissue cell-cell communication and electrophysiology in response to stochastic endogenous DNA damage. Deeper understanding of the regulatory network that mediates the genotoxic stress response in the cardiac tissue will suggest preventive strategies and therapeutic interventions to reduce public health burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because kidney function affects diseases from diabetes to hypertension to osteoporosis. Kidney inflammation resulting from acute kidney injury is often a slippery slope towards incurable chronic kidney disease. The proposed research of identifying the mechanisms by which renal lymphatic vessel density protects against kidney inflammation and preserves kidney function is thus highly relevant to the NIH’s mission of developing knowledge to improve human health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric brain cancer survivors are at increased risk for poor social connectedness, diminished health-related quality of life and reduced psychological well-being, though the associations between these factors and the underlying mechanisms impacting the trajectory of social connectedness are poorly understood. The proposed project will use an accelerated longitudinal design to compare the social connectedness and well-being among survivors of malignant and non-malignant brain tumors, determine the influence of social connectedness on health and well-being, and evaluate risk and mechanistic factors for social connectedness. Findings from this project will significantly advance our understanding of the importance of social connectedness in pediatric brain cancer survivorship and inform the development of effective interventions that target mechanistic factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Although the influence of social experiences on mental and physical health are commonly accepted, the biological drivers of these effects are not yet understood. Understanding the biological underpinnings of social modulation of neural health and behavior are critical to improved human health outcomes. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission because assessment of the effects of a common environmental factor underrepresented in research models will ultimately allow identification of novel intervention strategies to ameliorate adverse consequences of social disruption and lead to enhanced health and reduced disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vaccination safety is critical for individual and public health. Currently, vaccine trust is at an all-time low. The proposed ontology-based methods will provide important insights into the underlying mechanism of safety issues. Their development and applications to the VAERS dataset will contribute to public health by enabling earlier identification and prevention of potentially serious safety problems, reassuring the public that vaccines are safe, and recovering the public trust.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All living cells must synthesize and maintain proteins to carry out biological functions, but microorganisms frequently face environments that lack the nutrients to do so – both in external environments and during infection of hosts. How do microbes manage to continue producing and maintaining proteins when nutritional resources are scarce? Our research answers this question by examining the critical role of protein-helping molecules, known as chaperones, in enabling pathogenic bacteria to adjust key cellular processes and survive even while starving for essential molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) is the most common surgery for refractory ulcerative colitis and ulcerative colitis-related dysplasia, multiple complications can occur. Short and long-term complications include inflammatory conditions of the pouch such as acute and chronic pouchitis and Crohn’s-like disease of the pouch, each of which can require new medical treatments after surgery and can significantly impact the quality of life of individual patients. This mentored patient-oriented research career development project will generate evidence about the comparative effectiveness of therapies for the treatment of these inflammatory conditions of the pouch, will develop new IPAA-specific patient-reported assessments of pouch symptoms and quality of life, and will utilize precision medicine techniques including machine learning to identify patients at high-risk for developing chronic pouchitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research seeks to improve the safety and efficacy of implantable cardiovascular devices by establishing an autologous endothelium on the blood-contacting surface. This will minimize the risks of thrombosis and embolism while eliminating the need for anticoagulation therapy and the need for autologous vessel harvest during coronary bypass surgery. The proposed approach represents a novel combination of regenerative engineering and molecular modulation that may have broad applications throughout medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While being critical for protection from respiratory viral infection, lung resident memory T cells (Trm) wane with time; though the cause of this waning remains unclear. Our lab and others have demonstrated that this waning strongly correlates with the loss of heterosubtypic immunity to influenza A virus (IAV), indicating a critical importance for a more detailed understanding of Trm biology. The proposed study dissects the cause of IAV- specific lung Trm waning through functional, transcriptomic, and metabolic studies of T cell biology and defines vaccination strategies to re-invigorate this critical population of cells through innovative and clinically relevant mRNA-based vaccine platforms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Streptococcus pyogenes causes many diseases and is a leader of infectious morbidity and mortality responsible for >500,000 annual deaths. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms of retinal photoreceptor protein compartmentalization. Retinal degeneration and blindness may be caused by improper delivery of proteins to specialized regions within photoreceptors, the light detecting cells in our eyes. Understanding the mechanisms that control photoreceptor construction, and what goes wrong with this process in blinding diseases, will help find new therapies to extend or restore vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A central goal of our research program is to develop new platforms for the late-stage functionalization of small molecules and biomolecules. In recent years, these efforts have focused on the application of photoredox catalysis as a uniquely enabling paradigm in synthetic chemistry. Our aim is to harness this visible light-driven catalytic platform to (1) enable facile and efficient access to biologically active compounds of high interest and (2) expand the current toolbox for biological studies at the molecular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. T follicular helper cells (Tfh) are required to generate long-lasting antibody responses, which confer long-term protection to respiratory viruses. Thus, understanding how Tfh cell responses are created and maintained will allow us to design more efficient vaccines to pathogens such influenza virus, which is responsible for an average of 35,000 deaths annually in the US and has the potential of trigger world-wide pandemics. This proposal will define the mechanisms implicated in the generation of “high-quality” Tfh cell responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The diagnosis of HCC and assessment of its response to treatment rely primarily on imaging biomarkers which have replaced tissue-based measures. Recent studies demonstrate significant limitations of standard-of-care imaging paradigms for: (i) distinguishing HCCs from other tumors commonly observed in the liver, (ii) informing on the molecular and cellular biology required to facilitate treatment stratification and (iii) assessing treatment response. The development of the functional imaging strategies required to address these deficiencies has been limited by the absence of methodologies that can tailor imaging probe selection to the relevant HCC biology as well as a dearth of representative animal models. Using genome editing and metabolomics, our laboratory has demonstrated fundamental enzymatic dependencies of HCC cells to be promising imaging targets for diagnosis and treatment response assessment using Dynamic Nuclear Polarization 13Carbon Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopic Imaging, a novel and emerging imaging technology. The proposed project will build on this prior work to assess the accuracy of this technology for diagnosing and characterizing HCC and for treatment response assessment using unique translational animal models developed in our laboratory.

PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this research is to determine the operating modes of sensorimotor circuits during the detection and processing of sensory stimuli, and how these circuits mediate appropriate orienting responses to novel or meaningful stimuli. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aspergillus section Fumigati is a group of closely related species that vary considerably in their pathogenicity; whereas A. fumigatus is a major human pathogen and a few other species are also pathogenic, most species in the section are not pathogenic. To understand the observed variation in pathogenicity, our project will examine multiple biological and chemical traits known to influence pathogenicity in a comprehensive set of Aspergillus section Fumigati species and strains that span the pathogenicity spectrum. The results of our project will yield insights into the evolution of the traits and genetic elements important for Aspergillus pathogenicity and, more generally, into the evolution of fungal virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Migraine is highly prevalent and debilitating, considered a major public health concern, and its underlying pathobiology is not well understood. We propose to dissect a novel underlying mechanism, involving the production of reactive nitroxidative species, and their downstream alterations to glutamatergic signaling and neuroinflammatory mechanisms, which mediate nociceptive migraine-like responses. We will validate A3AR agonists as a solution for the treatment of migraine, by modulating these underlying molecular mechanisms, addressing this significant socioeconomic problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Inflammasomes are protein assemblies inside host cells that detect the presence of microbial pathogens including Gram-negative bacteria to alert the immune response. This proposal focuses on a new group of host immune proteins - the Guanylate Binding Proteins (GBPs) – that tailor the “non-canonical” inflammasome response specifically against Gram-negative bacteria such as Salmonella that are a major cause of food-borne gastroenteritis and blood-borne sepsis in U.S. intensive care units. Our efforts will uncover how GBPs control the “non-canonical” inflammasome that provides a conceptual framework for therapies aimed at treating life- threatening Gram-negative infections and sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research investigates the impact of early life exposure to environmental chemicals on the immune cells in the brain. Altered function of the immune cells early in life has been associated with increased risk of development of various neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases. Using imaging, genetic and behavioral approaches, the results of this research will provide fundmental knowledge about the effects of early life exposure to contaminants on the immune cells in the brain and the potential long-term consequences of neuroinflammation early in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Paraganglioma and pheochromocytoma are rare cancers that can run in families and can spread and kill patients. We are studying the unusual errors in gene recipes that cause these tumors. The current project uses a method to identify additional gene recipes required only by the tumor cells as clues to possible new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the modeling and incorporation of protein three-dimensional structures across the human proteome to further our ability to describe disease-related protein-protein interaction networks in tissue- and tumor-specific contexts. These structure-informed networks will reveal mechanistic insights regarding cellular processes underlying human diseases ranging from cancer to those resulting from viral and bacterial infection. Our results will also provide hypotheses regarding drugs that can target proteins in these networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative HIV is a chronic disease in which patients, even those well-treated, are at increased risk for heart disease when compared to the general population. Two hormones called aldosterone and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), which have been shown to be abnormal in HIV, may be associated with inflammation as well as early changes in structure and function of the heart. This study is being conducted to evaluate whether therapies to block aldosterone and increase BNP levels may reduce the burden and progression of heart failure—an important public health issue to improve cardiovascular health.

PHR: Influenza infection is a recurring public health burden and the need for better vaccines with that induce universal coverage is clear. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nanopore adaptive sampling will provide affordable, mobile sequencing for surveillance of tick vectors, rodent reservoirs, and tick-borne pathogens. We will test NAS for diagnostic accuracy (sensitivity, specificity, and threshold of detection), test for detection of a variety of in vitro grown DNA and RNA-based pathogens, differentiate closely related pathogen species and strains, develop and ground truth protocols for field testing on wild ticks and rodents from a well-characterized region, and comprehensively field test the methods and protocols in a region predicted to have the one of the highest densities of emerging rodent-associated zoonoses in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we will develop a new statistical framework to integrate genomic and transcriptomic data to define gene signatures that recapitulate the downstream oncogenic pathways underlying driver genomic aberrations in cancer. This framework will be utilized to perform secondary data analysis using a vast amount of existing cancer data generated from previous studies. Accomplishment of this project will lead to a comprehensive list of cancer-specific gene signatures and prediction models that can be used to stratify patients for directing personalized treatment in multiple cancer types, especially early-stage lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE … Adult patients with heart and lung failure are sometimes supported with temporary mechanical support called extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and its use has increased dramatically in the United States over the last 10 years. Although ECMO is a life-saving intervention for patients, a potential complication is acute brain injury. We will examine whether ECMO causes the production of blood clots that lodge in the brain and cause stroke and whether too much oxygen may contribute to injury in this proposal and understanding these risks may enable us to suggest changes to treatment that can be tested in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Seizure freedom is an elusive goal for the vast majority of the 1,000,000 Americans with drug-resistant epilepsy, yet pursuit of seizure freedom dominates epilepsy care and can overshadow other important determinants of quality of life (e.g. mental health or cognitive function). In this study, we will develop and test a mobile health tool for patients with drug-resistant epilepsy to facilitate communication of patient priorities to providers and thereby improve clinical outcomes. This work will advance a more patient-centered approach to the care of patients with neurologic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart disease, and this increased risk remains even if blood pressure is controlled. This proposal investigates the hypothesis that, in hypertension, excess activation of the mineralocorticoid receptor leads to two processes contributing to this excess risk: 1) impaired delivery of oxygen to the heart; and 2) impaired ability of the heart to generate mechanical energy and perform cardiac work. A clinical study using a mineralocorticoid receptor blocker will be performed to test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methylmercury (MeHg) is a potent neurotoxin in both the developing and mature central nervous system with apparent indiscriminate disruption of multiple homeostatic pathways and evidence of latent and persistence and latent effects long after exposure has subsided. Here we seek to identify and understand persistent and latent effects of MeHg toxicity on biological pathways impacted by MeHg toxicity. We aim to determine if it is formally possible that latent neurotoxicity can be stopped before neurological signs appear or that established persistent effects that continue long after exposure has ceased could be reversed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The highly adaptive ability to reduce responses to familiar, predictable stressors, termed habituation, is disrupted in several psychiatric disorders. Our work in adult rats shows that elevations in the expression and activity of the hypothalamic orexins disrupt habituation but whether orexin actions help to explain why adolescent animals do not habituate has not been studied. This proposal seeks to understand if elevations in orexin activity we observed in adolescent rats underlies their lack of ability to habituate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Many preclinical studies using transplanted tumor models demonstrate that radiotherapy can synergize with immune checkpoint inhibitors to generate systemic immune responses. However, clinical trials have shown that only a small percentage of patients respond well to dual therapies. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will characterize both the mechanisms through which radiation overcomes resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors, as well as the immune system's responses to upregulated neoantigen presentation after radiotherapy. Knowledge gained from this project may reveal novel targets for enhancing responses to immunotherapy in both sarcomas and other cancer types, and, thus, contributes to the NCI's mission to alleviate the burden of cancer in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Older adults have high rates of suicide yet there are no evidence-based interventions to prevent suicide deaths in later life. Social disconnection is a promising intervention target for late-life suicide prevention, but it is not known whether targeting social connection is an effective strategy to prevent suicide in later life. This study will test whether Social Engage Coaching (10 sessions of coaching to increase social connection) reduces suicide risk in later life (clinical outcome) via social connection (target mechanism).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall Narrative Building on progress from our previous IPCAVD, the goal of this program is to advance DNA launched nanoparticles bearing native like trimers which focus immune responses on apex and CD4bs B cell lineage targeted Envs (DLNP-ACE). Combining these novel immunogens with DNA- delivered genetic adjuvants to support vaccine-induced immunity represents a great leap forward in the design of HIV-1 vaccines. We have assembled an innovative team of experts in HIV vaccine immunogen design, DNA vaccine delivery, immune analysis, and infection models, and combined them with a clinical program partner, Inovio pharmaceuticals, which has extensive experience in cGMP production and clinical translation of DNA products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Optimization of Lead BKIs for Cryptosporidiosis Therapy The long-term objective of this research is to develop a new therapeutic for treatment of Cryptosporidium infection, which causes death and severe disease in malnourished children in resource-limited countries and immunocompromised individuals in the USA. In this proposal, we will rationally develop a drug with favorable properties that can serve as treatment of Cryptosporidium in the target population of malnourished children and immunocompromised individuals. At the end of the grant period, we expect to have a drug candidate that is ready to move towards human trials for therapy of cryptosporidiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Abnormal repetitive thoughts and behaviors are prominent, disabling, and notoriously-treatment resistant symptoms of many severe and highly comorbid childhood onset neuropsychiatric disorders such as Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD), Tourette Syndrome (TS), and autism. However, we still have a quite limited understanding of how these maladaptive behaviors are encoded in the brain. Defining the contribution of supplementary and pre-supplementary motor cortical regions to the generation and execution of perseverative thought patterns and repetitive actions may help develop new strategies for prevention and optimize existing neurostimulation protocols for these symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability and no current treatments exist beyond physical therapy. This proposal explores the mechanism of action of a biomaterial based therapy to promote recovery after stroke aiming to reduce stroke induced disability. Understanding the mechanism of action will provide new therapeutic targets to further improve recovery and reduce disability after stroke.
