IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Our proposed research will provide novel evidence on the effect of massive air pollution exposure on cardiometabolic health and how this exposure interacts with subsequent environmental exposures. Our study may uncover new health conditions linked to World Trade Center-related exposures and therefore has vast implications on health care costs and accessibility of treatment for World Trade Center responders and survivors. Moreover, evidence of extreme air pollution exposure as a source of population vulnerability can inform targeted interventions that reduce the risk of air pollution-related health outcomes among populations exposed to extreme air pollution events such as wildfires or smog.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is characterized increased lung vascular resistance, leading to right heart failure and death. Our proposal builds upon prior work implicating metabolic reprogramming in pulmonary artery smooth muscle cell in the development of pulmonary hypertension (PH). Further, we will evaluate novel therapies for treating these critically ill individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) disproportionately affects rural areas, where CRC screening falls far below national guidelines. Although evidence-based CRC interventions exist, many rural primary care practices have not implemented these interventions. Therefore, in partnership with the Indiana Rural Health Association, we propose a study to test implementation of an evidence-based CRC intervention into primary care practices to increase CRC screening and support future implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The intractable amotivation symptom in schizophrenia generates a debilitating condition with a substantial public health burden due to a lack of mechanistic understanding of the underlying neural circuits. The proposed research will use a genetic mouse line to selectively isolate and pinpoint a novel circuit that underlies the amotivation phenotype. The results of these experiments are positioned to provide a circuit-specific mechanism that can be manipulated to help inform therapeutic strategies to alleviate amotivation in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Residual cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk in patients on lipid lowering therapy is a major unmet clinical need. Our goal is to investigate mechanisms of plaque stabilization and destabilization focused on functions of vascular smooth muscle cell (SMC) derived cells (SDCs), and their crosstalk with macrophages (Mϕ), in mouse models and human CVD. Our work will provide mechanistic insight into the role of SDC types, their lesion domain locations and neighboring cells, and crosstalk with Mϕ to achieve our overall goal of greater mechanistic understanding of factors affecting atherosclerotic plaque stability and instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to establish the University of Iowa as a translational research infrastructure to efficiently conduct rigorous and innovative comparative studies of cerebroprotection in the context of reperfusion, in collaboration with the NIH Stroke Preclinical Assessment Network (SPAN). The goal is to identify which cerebroprotective treatments are likely to improve the outcomes of the 800,000 Americans who suffer a stroke and are currently treated with reperfusion strategies that have limited effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain afflicts millions of patients; yet, treatments are largely ineffective and development of new, targeted therapies is limited by gaps in our knowledge regarding its underlying neural circuitry. This project will investigate a group of neurons that we recently discovered and that we propose represent an important component of descending pain modulation circuitry. Defining fundamental characteristics of this novel descending pathway involved in pain modulation, including its functional connectivity, synaptic mechanisms and its role in acute and chronic pain states, will ultimately help to better understand the neural circuitry of pain and may lead to more efficacious and better targeted therapeutics for treating acute and chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to establish senescent regulatory T cells as the cellular target for renal clear cell carcinoma by using Proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) technology that leads to the degradation of pro- survival BCL-XL protein. We have found that BCL-XL PROTAC can induce the apoptosis of tumor-infiltrating Tregs. Using in vivo models and cancer specimens, we will determine the efficacy of senolytic targeting BCL-XL by combining with other frontline therapeutics and provide a rationale to target BCL-XL for cancer immunotherapy for renal cell carcinomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Heart attacks result from changes within the walls of arteries (blood vessels) in the heart. We know that when the inner lining of an artery is damaged, a blood clot sometimes forms and blocks the vessel severely enough to cause a heart attack. At other times, however, through processes that are not well-understood, the damage to the lining is repaired spontaneously, clot formation is prevented, and no heart attack occurs. The studies we propose here are designed to understand processes and factors that affect repair of the inner lining of the vessel, so we can use this knowledge to prevent or reduce the occurrence of heart attacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pontocerebellar hypoplasia (PCH), a severe neurological disorder for which there is no cure that is caused by mutations in several RNA processing complexes. The aims of this proposal will determine how several PCH-linked complexes assemble, recognize and process RNA, how they are enzymatically and spatially regulated, and how PCH mutations disrupt their function. This work is essential to better understand how these complexes function normally in healthy states and how their dysfunction leads to PCH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The research in this VA Merit will examine the effects of obesity and Post-COVID Conditions (PCC) on physical functioning, health-related quality of life, and adipose tissue inflammatory and cellular senescence profiles in older Veterans. Further, it will evaluate whether a weight loss intervention, including dietary modification and exercise, in obese Veterans with and without PCC will reduce systemic and adipose tissue inflammation and senescence and promote PCC recovery. This research is especially relevant to older Veterans as two-thirds of Veterans are overweight or obese, rendering excess adiposity a significant risk factor and a high- priority area related to COVID-19 prevention and care. This study also will explore potential mechanisms by which systemic and adipose tissue inflammation and senescence influences the pathophysiology of physical, mental, and social dysfunction in older Veterans recovering from COVID-19. Our findings could lead to novel lifestyle and pharmacologic strategies to optimize COVID-19 recovery.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Cognitive aging, characterized by declines in memory and thinking abilities, is one of the most important issues facing older Veterans. As the Veteran population ages, the number of Veterans at risk for cognitive decline increases. Veterans are also more likely to have psychological, physical, and social conditions directly tied to their service that increase their risk for cognitive decline. Luckily, over the past two decades there has been an increased appreciation for the role of lifestyle interventions to improve brain health, with research showing that participation in consistent exercise, healthy diet, sufficient sleep, socialization, and engagement in cognitively stimulating activities can reduce dementia risk. The goal of this project is to determine the effect of a multi- component intervention designed to provide education about brain aging, improve feelings of control over brain aging, and deliver practical assistance with creation of an executable action plan. These types of interventions are are critically needed to improve the brain health of aging Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) can develop liver cirrhosis due to alcohol and substance abuse. PTSD and cirrhosis often co-exist, but research on these conditions has progressed separately till now. These conditions are also associated with changes in gut microbes, which can affect the brain negatively. We propose as part of a collaboration of several proposals entitled “Targeting Gut-Microbiome in Veterans Deployment related Gastrointestinal and Liver diseases” to study changes in the gut microbes as a potential treatment target in Veterans with cirrhosis and PTSD. We will perform this by enrolling 320 Veterans from two large VA sites, 80 each of whom will be healthy, 80 will have PTSD only, 80 with cirrhosis only and 80 with PTSD+Cirrhosis. We will study their gut microbes, which will be linked to brain function, and severity of PTSD symptoms. For the second aim, we will transfer stool from affected Veterans into germ-free mice to define which microbes are responsible for the gut, liver and brain changes and can be specifically targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wilms tumor is the most common kidney cancer in children and accounts for 6% of pediatric cancer. Patients who have tumors with diffuse anaplasia (unfavorable histology) have dismal prognoses. The purpose of this project is to understand the fundamental biology of how WT1 functions as an oncogene in anaplastic Wilms tumor. This project could lead to new treatment strategies which directly or indirectly target WT1 in anaplastic Wilms tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Community pharmacies play an important role in the health care system: they are frequently accessed and have increasing capacity to deliver HIV prevention services. In communities where the prevalence of HIV is high and access to antenatal care clinics is delayed or infrequent, there is a unique opportunity to leverage pharmacies to enhance early and sustained access to HIV prevention among pregnant women. This study will identify women’s preferences for delivery of HIV prevention services and provider-level and system-level strategies to design a new pharmacy-based model of care for pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The U.S. Surgeon General recently announced the use (vaping) of electronic cigarettes (e-cigs) as a major public health concern. Utilizing a state-of-the-art custom-engineered vaping system with an atomizer identical to those sold in vape shops world-wide, the proposed studies discerning the health effects of e-cigs during pregnancy will allow effective education of the public and will facilitate applicable policy implementation regarding the potential risks these devices pose to the public. The proposed studies directly address a stated consensus recommendation of the most recent NIH/NHLBI workshop on cardiovascular disease and the emergence of e-cigs, i.e. investigating effects of e-cigarette aerosol exposure in pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV prevention and care interventions, including Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP), could effectively end the HIV epidemic, however, more research and training focused on implementation strategies to ensure PrEP is implemented effectively in public clinics is needed. This K24 provides protected time to Dr. Lippman to extend her current implementation research, broaden her mentoring program, and expand opportunities for early career investigators to engage in cutting edge implementation science research to address barriers to PrEP delivery in South Africa and Brazil. This work can improve PrEP delivery for health disparity populations with poor access to tailored HIV prevention and ensure a pipeline of trainees in the US and abroad who are well equipped in the application of implementation science approaches to stimulate new research and independent research careers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current and future shortage of cardiothoracic surgeons and the extremely diverse clinical activities and broad array of conditions treated by cardiac and thoracic surgeons is an emergent unmet need that demands a training program in cardiothoracic surgery. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease, caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, is associated with a spectrum of clinical symptoms and a dramatic range in severity among infected individuals. A forward genetics approach identified a locus on Chr 4 of the mouse that regulates Lyme arthritis by controlling the expression of Type I IFN, and downstream induction of MSTN as an effector of arthritis development. The mechanism by which Type I IFN and MSTN contribute to Lyme arthritis development will be addressed, with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets for patients with severe disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Biliary atresia (BA) is a cholestatic liver disease of infancy that is the leading cause of pediatric liver transplantation. Evidence suggests a role for macrophages in the pathogenesis of BA, however, the specific subpopulations that promote inflammation and ongoing liver injury have not been determined. We aim to define the distinct role of macrophage subsets in the disease mechanism of BA and ultimately identify novel cell subset- specific treatment strategies to improve disease outcome for children with BA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Transport of nucleoside chemotherapeutic drugs is primarily accomplished in mammalian cells through Equilibrative Nucleoside Transporter 1 (ENT1), considered constitutively on, redistributing drugs across a bilayer via facilitated diffusion. Preliminary evidence, however, indicates that ENT1 transport of the chemotherapeutic gemcitabine in endothelial cells requires gemcitabine-induced acid sphingomyelinase (ASMase) activation, formation of ceramide-rich platforms (CRPs) on the external plasma membrane, and ENT1 insertion into CRPs for optimized transport function. We propose the existence of a previously- unrecognized form of chemoresistance involving suppression of ENT1 function, reversible by pharmacologic activation of ASMase/Ceramide Signaling.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT / PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelomeningocele is a permanently disabling birth defect; while state-of-the-art treatment can improve motor outcomes, cognitive disabilities are expected for most affected individuals. This project aims to assess sleep- disordered breathing as a potentially remediable contributor to the abnormal cognitive outcomes for children with myelomeningocele. The study goals are directly relevant to the NIH mission, which calls for the prevention and treatment of disease to enhance health and reduce disability, and to enable all individuals to achieve their full potential and live more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  It remains difficult to effectively alleviate asthmatic symptoms and limit disease progression in children with severe asthma. While corticosteroids can be effective, children with severe asthma develop corticosteroid insensitivity or resistance making their disease difficult to manage. The goal of this proposal is to understand how inflammation promotes corticosteroid resistance in the context of severe pediatric asthma. These studies are also aimed to assess the potential for therapeutic strategies to improve corticosteroid sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this application, we hypothesize that the mammalian body possesses special small spaces within tissues, where stem cells are shielded from immune attack. This sanctuary for stem cells may protect transplanted stem cells from immune attack, and further shield cancer cells from immune attack and tumor immunotherapy, resulting in the relapse following the cancer treatment. We will validate this hypothesis to uncover new disease mechanisms, and further develop novel therapeutic strategies to manipulate the oasis for stem cells to improve the outcome of stem cell transplantation and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Complement activation is believed to play a major role in the development of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) in humans. Studies in animal models identify specific processes that appear to allow complement to be activated and result in tissue destruction. However, important gaps remain in our knowledge of the roles of complement in patients with RA. A better understanding of the role of complement and the underlying causes of dysregulation of this pathway in patients will not only provide important translational science insights but also help to identify new targets and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sarbecoviruses have crossed from bats to humans twice in the last two decades via viruses that emerged from distinct locations on the sarbecovirus evolutionary tree. Investigating sarbecoviruses from points on the evolutionary tree that have not already crossed the species barrier can yield important insight into differences in structure and antigenicity will allow for the development of tools to respond rapidly to future spillover of sarbecoviruses. I propose to investigate the structure, receptor usage and antigenicity of clade 3 sarbecoviruses to prepare a foundation upon which timely responses to spillover can be built.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Coordination of presynaptic neurotransmitter release and postsynaptic reception of that signal is fundamental for information processing in the brain, but the local signals that control this form of “synaptic homeostasis” are not well understood. This issue is important as significant links to neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders have now been attributed to defects in the process by which trans-synaptic communication is tuned and maintained in active brain circuits, and thus a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved may lead to novel treatments for neurological disease. Our work addresses the critical role of the mTOR complex 1 signaling cascade in allowing the postsynaptic neuron to coordinate neurotransmitter release from its presynaptic partners, with the current project focused on the activity-dependent recruitment of the protein degradation machinery to axonal terminals as a fundamental requirement for homeostatic coordination of presynaptic and postsynaptic function. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is responsible for a significant portion of oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma and the HPV E7 protein facilitates degradation of host tumor suppressor PTPN14, promoting activation and nuclear translocation of YAP1 oncoprotein in general keratinocyte models of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. This activity of E7 leading to YAP1 activation by PTPN14 degradation has not been studied in oropharyngeal models of carcinoma and the overall pathway for PTPN14-dependent YAP1 regulation remains largely unknown. In this proposal I will determine if PTPN14 degradation by E7 is activating YAP1 in HPV-positive OPSCC cells and establish details of the mechanism for YAP1 phosphorylation and inhibition by PTPN14.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An ear infection (otitis media) is the most common reason for a child to see a doctor in the United States and is, therefore, an extremely important public health problem. Making matters worse, doctors have a great deal of difficulty making an accurate diagnosis of an ear infection because it is hard to look at a child’s ear and even when the doctor gets a good look, they can only see the ear drum and not the place behind the ear drum where the infection is happening. This research plan will use a new technology (optical coherence tomography), which is a like an ultrasound for the ear, to see if this technology can make it easier for doctors to make the right diagnosis in children with ear infections and reduce the number of antibiotics and surgeries that are needed for ear infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While cold exposure blocks peripheral sensory signaling in most mammals, the hibernating thirteen-lined ground squirrel preserves touch sensation (mechanosensation) at a body temperature of 2-4°C. This proposal utilizes physiological and molecular methods to identify the modifications at dorsal root ganglion ion channels underlying cold-resistant mechanosensation. Understanding cellular mechanisms of extreme thermal tolerance in the mammalian nervous system will provide new targets for the mitigation of neuronal damage following organ supercooling or perioperative hypothermia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the 2nd leading cause of cancer death in the United States. A lifestyle consistent with the American Cancer Society (ACS) Nutrition and Physical Activity Guidelines is associated with approximately 40% lower risk of death in people with colorectal cancer, but few colorectal cancer survivors follow the guidelines. This study will use an innovative framework to identify an intervention to improve physical activity, diet, and body size among colorectal cancer survivors that can be remotely delivered and broadly accessible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antipsychotic treatment, which is known to cause differential age-related weight gain and related cardiometabolic risk (CMR) conditions in mentally ill populations, is an optimal example of how precision medicine approaches could rapidly impact treatment outcomes. This proposal leverages the existence of large population-based studies and hospital-based biobanks with randomized clinical trial data from studies funded by NIH, PCORI and pharma, and will apply genomics and novel molecular techniques, including array-based genotyping, CRISPR screening and cellular functional studies to understand the genetic risk for and mechanisms underlying antipsychotic-induced weight gain and associated CMR, from childhood to older adulthood. If funded, this project will substantially contribute to the understanding of mechanisms of accelerated aging associated with weight gain, and the development of an analytic algorithm that will eventually be able to predict and prevent antipsychotic-related weight gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The control of protein function by modulation of its structure and dynamics is of significant therapeutic benefit to human health. One of the hurdles to such control is a more complete understanding of how different regions in a protein architecture interact with one another. This proposal will fill this void through a collaborative effort combining biophysical experiments and computational methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  We propose to conduct a well-powered transcriptome-wide association study and methylation-wide association study to discover novel genes and methylation markers for lung cancer risk. We will also evaluate the differences in the expression levels of TWAS-identified genes and the methylation levels of MeWAS- identified loci between lung cancer tissues and normal tissues, investigate the regulating effects of methylation sites on the expression of promising genes by functional genomics analyses, and perform functional analyses to evaluate the potential functions of identified genes and methylation loci. Our results will help us to better understand the mechanistic relationship between genetic and epigenetic variations and how those variations relate to lung cancer risk and may lead to the discovery of biomarkers that would facilitate early detection of lung cancer and the development of targeted gene therapies for personalized treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The project will provide new insights into mechanisms underlying complex genomic changes resulting from DNA rearrangements - a common cause of neurological disease. This will enable better diagnostics and potential new avenues for therapy by the correction of gene dosage further supporting the Precision Medicine Initiative. Such genomic rearrangements cause gene copy number variations resulting in neurodevelopmental disorders including intellectual disability, behavioral disorders such as autism, psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with Type 1 diabetes have higher fracture rates and smaller and weaker muscles compared to those without diabetes, even in young ages. With this project we will try to identify whether a molecule that comes from skeletal muscle, called myostatin, is involved in the increased risk of fractures and the poor quality of skeletal muscle in young individuals with Type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our study will provide new insights into the control and manipulation of the p53 pathway, one of the most important pathway protecting human cells against the development of cancer. Specifically, it will give a quantitative understanding of how p53 is controlled in individual cells; how it turns appropriate genes on and off, how this control is misregulated in cancers; and how therapeutic strategies to manipulate p53 activity can be combined with other cancer treatments to eliminate tumor cells. The knowledge gained from these studies will advance our understanding of how p53 operates in normal and cancer cells and help translate our insights to address important clinical needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Black very low birth weight infants are significantly less likely to receive mother’s own milk. The costs associated with adhering to pumping are borne by mothers and contribute to this disparity. This randomized controlled trial will test an intervention to offset costs associated with pumping and its cost effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) aims to translate years of basic research into clinical practice by providing early evidence-based language and comprehension intervention to those most vulnerable for reading comprehension failure. This project is relevant to the NIDCD's mission to improve the lives of individuals with communication disorders because findings from the proposed studies are expected to be informative for refinement of prognosis and treatment methods for this population, which includes children with low language comprehension, many of whom have Developmental Language Disorder (DLD). This project is also relevant to the broader field of public health because of the importance of language and literacy skills to quality of life outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The integration of color and form is an enriching and often necessary component of visual perception. Thus, deficits and abnormalities in visual feature integration, common to many ophthalmologic and neuropsychiatric disorders, are debilitating to those afflicted. This proposal will expand our fundamental understanding of how the brain processes color and integrates it into visual space, paving the way to possible therapies for visual processing deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fast and efficient neurotransmission is essential for normal brain function, and a thorough understanding of how synapses are organized is essential to our understanding of neurological diseases. The pre-synaptic calcium sensor Synaptotagmin VII (SYT7) has been recently linked to Bipolar Disorder, ALS and numerous cancers, yet its localization in neurons remains debated. Here, we will answer key outstanding questions surrounding SYT7 by determining its cellular and nanoscale localization at synapses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histotripsy is a noninvasive, nonthermal and nonionizing ablation modality that has recently undergone a successful phase I human clinical trial. However, a critical limitation to more widespread adoption is the reliance on fixed 2D ultrasound for targeting the tumor, monitoring the ablation, and assessing the ablation zone. In this grant, we will develop a C-arm based platform to accurately and automatically target liver tissue for histotripsy as well as validate prospectively in real-time the performance of the platform in in vivo large animal (porcine, rabbit VX2) models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social memory is essential for the human experience – remembering others enables us to form relationships and successfully navigate through society. The social memory deficits common to many neuropsychiatric disorders are thus debilitating. This proposal will expand our fundamental understanding of how the brain forms and recalls lasting social memories, paving the way to possible therapies for social memory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac arrest impacts the lives of 500,000 Americans every year, and nearly half of patients surviving the initial resuscitation will develop seizures or seizure-like brain activity as a complication of hypoxic-ischemic brain injury. We aim to reduce secondary brain injury and neurological disability from seizures after cardiac arrest by personalizing seizure treatment using EEG and brain MRI biomarkers of neuro-recovery. We expect that the outcome of the proposed studies will provide critical knowledge about epileptogenesis after hypoxic-ischemic brain injury andguide the development of goal-directed seizure treatment and patient selection in future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phase 1 trials are a critical first step in the search for new treatments and cures for serious neurological diseases. In order to conduct these studies ethically, research ethics committees must determine both that the risks of the trials are reasonable in relation to their potential benefits and that research candidates are given the key information they need in order to understand the potential risks and benefits in such a trial. These committees currently are not provided with instructions from the Department of Health and Human Services for determining whether there is a reasonable ratio between risks and benefits or what counts as the key information about them that need to be disclosed to research candidates. This project will develop and test new strategies and materials that can assist research ethics committees to make these critical determinations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer related deaths worldwide and many patients eventually stop responding to treatments including immunotherapies, so a better understanding of why patients stop responding will help us develop strategies to overcome this challenge. My current work uses novel mouse models of lung cancer to investigate mechanisms of acquired resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors, whereas my postdoctoral work will focus on developing efficacious neoantigen vaccines that induce tissue resident memory T cells. In both settings, my overarching goal is to produce strategies to expand immunotherapy benefits to a broader patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Numerous intestinal diseases, including necrotizing enterocolitis and inflammatory bowel dis- ease, have disruption of the intestinal barrier. Absence of the bile acid receptor FXR protects animals from acute intestinal injury by maintaining their intestinal barrier. Because FXR may be responsible for gut barrier failure in acute injury, this research proposal will explore the signaling cascades involved in these effects with relevance to human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases are devastating for individuals and families involved; there are no cures and few treatments. Our studies have revealed new insights into ALS contributors TDP-43 and FUS/TLS, defined a new genetic risk factor for ALS – mutations in the ataxin 2 gene and discovered a cellular process to explain how mutations in the C9orf72 gene, the most common known cause of ALS, might contribute to neurodegeneration. The studies proposed will reveal insight into the role of dipeptide repeat proteins abnormally produced from the C9orf72 mutation and will pursue ataxin 2 as a therapeutic target in ALS, laying the foundation for the development of novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Coronary revascularization (i.e., stent placement) has been adopted worldwide and is the most common modality in patients with coronary heart diseases in the United States. However, it is also among the most costly and is often associated with a high incidence of restenosis (repeat narrowing of a coronary artery). This application aims to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for restenosis and thus identify new therapeutic targets to develop new drugs to treat restenosis after coronary revascularization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The ability to sense force is critical for myriad functions in the body, yet the molecular mechanisms of force-sensing are the least understood among all sensory systems. We identified the mechanically-activated Piezo2 ion channel, and showed that it plays a critical role in detecting touch, proprioception and lung stretch, but not noxious mechanical stimuli. In this proposal, we describe approaches we will take to explore the roles of Piezo2 in various forms of internal-organ mechanotransduction and to identify the elusive receptors involved in mechanical pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Uterine fibroids (leiomyomas) are tumors that affect up to 80% of all women during their lifetime and constitute a major health problem worldwide. MED12 gene mutations occur in approximately 70% of all leiomyomas, and endocrine disruptors are known risk factors; we do not know, however, how these genetic or environmental factors cause tumor growth. We propose to determine the role of the tryptophan-kynurenine-aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) pathway that is activated by these factors in tumorigenesis. We expect that our proposal will lead to a better understanding of this understudied disease and future development of new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Oxycodone is consistently among medications widely prescribed for pain, but is also widely abused and involved in overdose deaths -- creating an urgent need for interventions that preserve oxycodone analgesia while curtailing its abuse potential. Research shows that syntocinon (the intranasal formulation of the neuropeptide oxytocin) could reduce the abuse liability of opioids, and simultaneously has analgesic properties. The present study will determine if syntocinon will significantly reduce the abuse potential of oxycodone and experimental pain via its effects on brain structure, function and biochemistry, which could lead to a novel therapeutic to curb the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative IL-12 is a powerful cytokine that stimulates both the adaptive and innate immune system to eliminate cancer but safe delivery of therapeutically active doses has been a major barrier to its widespread clinical use. In this application, we will test two unique and potent methods of delivering the IL-12 gene into cancerous tumors in a clinical trial of pet dogs that have naturally developed soft tissue tumors. If successful, this project will both answer fundamental questions regarding the biology of IL-12 and lead to the clinical development of a new of cancer treatment in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Knee Biofeedback Rehabilitation Interface for Game-based Home Therapy (“KneeBRIGHT”) system aims to motivate patients with knee osteoarthritis to engage in regular muscle strengthening exercise through an engaging, EMG-driven video game therapy. KneeBRIGHT will enhance rehabilitation by: (1) increasing functional recovery through physical practice of evidence-based exercise routines; (2) promoting adherence through fun activities and real-time performance feedback; (3) providing a low-cost option for effective home therapy; (4) creating reliable tracking mechanisms for patient adherence and functional status; and (5) increasing access to care in remote, underserved areas.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work aims to understand the organization and function of the brain systems that support human memory and to illuminate the nature of memory disorders. We are studying individuals with memory impairment due to brain injury, and we are studying healthy volunteers using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). The neuropathology has been thoroughly documented quantitatively with MRI. Memory problems are commonly reported in conjunction with neurological and psychiatric illness and are a significant issue in veterans’ health. Improved knowledge about how memory works, and about how memory fails after injury or disease, lays a foundation for the development of interventions to help diagnose, treat, and prevent the diseases that affect memory, including Alzheimer’s disease. Better knowledge about how memory works, and how to measure it, also provides a foundation for improved assessment of memory impairment, which is increasingly significant in Veterans returning from combat and in aging Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Many promising drug candidates fail to advance clinically due to issues with systemic toxicity, the inability to appropriately reach target tissues/cells, and improper synergy with combinatorial partners. We take a unique approach to overcome these limitations using bottlebrush polymer prodrugs that allow for tissue-selective drug release, precise delivery of combinatorial therapeutics at specific ratios, and cell-selective targeting through tunable antibody-brush polymer conjugates. In addition, we adapt this technology to achieve real-time MRI imaging of cellular and molecular processes that can be used to non-invasively evaluate pharmacological efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Postoperative delirium is a common, costly, and potentially fatal complication that is strongly associated with aging, Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and other forms of dementia. The goal of the project is to establish the role of neural circuits affected early in AD and aging on prodromal cognitive function and risk of postoperative delirium using clinically relevant behavioral testing paradigms in a rat model of AD. The proposed studies implement chemogenetic tools to identify specific therapeutic targets for POD intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Life expectancy in the US has not kept pace with other countries recently due to the rise in mortality related to drug overdose, suicide, and alcohol as well as stalled progress in preventing cardiometabolic mortality. This study uses two longitudinal samples with twenty years of follow-up merged with rich place-based data to understand how structural, social, built, and environmental features prospectively affect individual-level substance misuse, mental health, cardiometabolic health, and mortality. This comprehensive research effort will produce novel evidence to support the development of effective place-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroblastoma is the most common solid malignant tumor of childhood and accounts for approximately 15% of all deaths due to pediatric cancers. High-risk neuroblastoma is often characterized by the expression of amplified MYCN for which no direct inhibitors have yet been generated. We propose to take advantage of the increased requirement for protein synthesis in MYCN-amplified cells by exploring therapeutic inhibition of translation initiation using novel rocaglate derivatives that are expected to provide selective targeting of this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will address a critical emerging public health concern by elucidating the cerebrovascular and microstructural brain changes following COVID-19 infection that may predispose aging adults to long-term cognitive impairment or neurodegenerative changes. By examining how COVID-19-related brain and cognitive measures differ by sex and are modified Alzheimer’s disease genetic risk and pathology, results are expected to help identify individuals at greatest risk for adverse COVID-19-related neurological outcomes and to guide personalized approaches for risk assessment and treatment. This project will support the mission of the NIH by clarifying how COVID-19 impacts neurobiological aging and may amplify an already grave public health crisis of age-related cognitive decline and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Nitric oxide (NO) regulates vascular tone and blood pressure; however, the process of vascular NO metabolism is not well understood. We have shown that the recently discovered globin, Cytoglobin (Cgb), is expressed in smooth muscle and functions to regulate NO metabolism in the vessel wall, in turn, modulating vascular tone. We will determine how the NO degrading and antioxidant properties of Cgb control NO and redox metabolism in normal and hypertensive vessels, and how this in turn regulates vessel tone and blood pressure in normal physiology and cardiovascular disease, leading to development of novel therapeutics to reverse vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall objective of the Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Environmental Health Sciences (SURES) program is to use a research-intensive approach for introducing students from the impoverished region of Appalachia to the multidisciplinary nature of environmental sciences and opportunities for pursuing relevant careers. Exceptional training in a wide variety of research areas working with interdisciplinary collaborative research groups who are housed in multiple departments and colleges is provided. In addition, seminars, outreach opportunities and interactive workshops are designed to prepare students for successful, environmental health related careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE The objective of this grant is to study the detailed molecular and cellular mechanisms by which different forms of chronic stress alter specific types of neurons within the brain's reward circuitry. We focus on changes at the chromatin—or epigenetic—level as mediators of particularly long-lasting effects of stress exposure. These studies will provide new information concerning how chronic stress causes lifelong changes in stress susceptibility and, in turn, identify novel leads toward the development of improved treatments for stress- related disorders in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our primary research goal is to understand the function of long non-coding RNAs in the cardiovascular system. In this project, we will examine whether the large intergenic non-coding RNA called lincRNAp21 can alleviate pressure overload induced cardiac hypertrophy, a medical condition that is a leading cause of death worldwide and highly relevant to the mission of the NIH. Our studies using mutant mouse models are designed to be translated into novel therapeutic strategies to treat patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tourette Syndrome (TS) is a complex disorder, for which there is no cure and efforts to develop novel treatments are hampered by our limited understanding of the neurobiology and brain structural and functional deficits that underlie the disorder. TS is also highly heterogeneous and often comorbid with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD), Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), and Anxiety Disorder (AXD), further complicating our efforts. Leveraging ties to ENIGMA and an international network of collaborators, we will pursue the largest neuroimaging and genetics studies for TS to date, pooling, harmonizing and jointly analyzing worldwide datasets for TS and highly comorbid disorders shedding light into TS neurobiology and identifying biomarkers that could help tailor individualized management approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remodeling of microvessels in the retina from hypertension may be a clue to vascular risk factors of cognitive decline during aging. Our proposal will begin to advance understanding of the retinal microvessels as a biomarker of hypertensive effects on cognitive function. Results from our proposed studies will contribute new knowledge about the hypertension-related mechanisms of dementia, one of public health and social care priorities worldwide with a rapid aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project examines the role of domestic and international migration in determining area-level mortality rates and geographic inequality in mortality across counties, metropolitan areas, states, and regions of the United States between 1990 and present, as well as cross-national inequalities in mortality among 18 high- income countries. In addition to investigating how low-mortality migrants may decrease average mortality rates of specific areas, we assess how migrants impact the mortality rates of non-migrants by making areas where they settle better places to live. The findings inform our understanding of how policies relating to migration may have short- and long-term effects on place-based health and health inequalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although all drugs must be tested for their potential to cause ventricular arrhythmia as an adverse event, the probability of an arrhythmia depends on both the drug and the characteristics of the particular patient. This research will advance the use of mathematical models to predict the risk of drug-induced arrhythmia, particularly by developing a platform to assess how patient demographics and comorbidities interact with drugs to increase or decrease personalized risk.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Memory impairment has a significant impact on a Veteran's ability to lead a productive and fulfilling life, affecting an array of cognitive functions, including the ability to make well-informed healthcare decisions, and directly influencing quality of life. I study the cognitive and neural bases of memory impairment in patients with severe global amnesia as a result of lesions to the medial temporal lobes. Although global amnesia is rare, disruption of the medial temporal lobe memory system occurs in many neurological and psychiatric disorders that affect the Veteran population. Thus, insights gained from the study of amnesia can be applied to the study of other clinical populations. I have examined the impact of memory impairment in Veterans with traumatic brain injury, and currently study how memory impairment may contribute to the development and maintenance of symptoms associated with posttraumatic stress disorder. My work promises to guide clinical assessment of Veterans with memory impairment and may offer new targets for theoretically informed interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Sleep apnea (SA) is increased in intact and spinal cord injured Veterans and is linked to autonomic, cardiovascular, metabolic and neurocognitive dysfunction. Thus, the development of novel treatments to mitigate associated co-morbidities is imperative. We are exploring the role that serotonin has in exacerbating SA in spinal cord injury, using a non‐anesthetized spontaneously breathing mouse model with or without genetic depletion of central nervous system serotonin. We are also exploring in Veterans if repeated daily exposure to mild intermittent hypoxia (MIH) mitigates co-morbidities linked to SA. We propose MIH targets numerous co- morbidities and initiates respiratory plasticity that enhances upper airway stability. Increased stability could reduce the therapeutic pressure required to treat SA and improve treatment compliance resulting in a secondary pathway to mitigate co-morbidities linked to SA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Attachment of bacteria to tissue surfaces is often the first step in an infection, but how bacteria sense surfaces is poorly understood. The bacterial flagellar motor, which propels bacteria through fluids, is now believed to be a mechanosensor responsible for sensing surfaces. This project will investigate how the motor senses and transduces mechanical forces and will aid in developing preventive or therapeutic strategies against harmful bacterial biofilms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is an important cause of cardiovascular disease morbidity and mortality and affects 46% of Americans. Inflammation and associated immunopathogenesis are key contributors to the development of hypertension. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Frailty is defined as a greater susceptibility to stressors resulting from age-related impairments in adaptive biological systems. Frailty leads to poorer physical performance and functional capacity and higher risk of adverse outcomes including falls, hospitalization, and mortality. Resilience, defined as the capacity to recover from disruptions to homeostasis, is critical to successful aging because it precedes frailty and enhances adults’ ability to maintain optimal health and function well into older age. Evidence-based therapies to help older adults enhance resilience are limited and the biological underpinnings contributing to improved resilience have not yet been fully characterized. To address this important need, we will conduct a clinical trial to examine the benefits of center- and home-based high intensity interval training (HIIT) on functional capacity, frailty, and resilience, and also to identify novel biomarkers of resilience in older Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In the human malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum, the lack of knowledge regarding most essential processes and regulatory pathways, particularly in the mitochondria, is a critical barrier to identifying and developing new drug targets. Ideally these targets are highly conserved and should be resistant to mutation or have limited ability to change in order to evolve resistance. This proposal outlines methods to identify and define previously unknown and uncharacterized aspects of parasite mitochondrial biology, with the goal of advancing rational drug design against this deadly parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a common cause of upper and lower respiratory tract infections and immunocompromised individuals (e.g. infants, young children and elderly) are at particularly high risk of severe infection and disease.  There is no FDA-approved vaccine currently available to treat RSV and other therapies have either limited efficacy and/or are plagued by adverse side-effects.  In this proposal, we will apply our proprietary NanoVaxTM nanoemulsion adjuvant technology to enable future manufacturing of a potent RSV vaccine that is safe, and facilitates intranasal delivery to confer protective, mucosal immunity against the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Heavy and persistent alcohol use has clear harmful effects on the gut and its microbiome, such as leaky gut and inflammatory bowel disease, while recent research suggests cannabis may have systemic effects that are opposite to those of alcohol, such as reducing or preventing alcohol-induced liver, bowel and systemic inflammation. Furthermore, psychological processes such as emotion regulation have a bidirectional relationship with the gut microbiome through the gut-brain axis and are heavily associated with inflammation as well. This proposal aims to examine these relationships through the modulation of signaling within the endocannabinoid system, which interacts with the brain, gut microbiome and immune system, and could be the basis for a proposed endocannabinoid-microbiota-gut-brain axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: As the third most common cause of death in the United States following heart disease and cancer, sepsis represents a prevalent and deadly public health issue, but alarmingly, there are no approved therapeutics available for sepsis once antibiotics and supportive therapy fail. Current mouse models used to study sepsis make use of laboratory animals that are relatively devoid of memory T cells—immune cells which are generated in humans as a result of exposure to microbial pathogens. Here, we interrogate a critical pathway (CD28) that regulates the function of memory T cells during sepsis; therapeutic targeting of this pathway will lead to improvements in sepsis-induced immune dysregulation and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand how selfish genetic elements known as transposons are able to remain active in the genomes of most organisms despite the existence of highly specialized pathways used by host genomes to identify them and suppress their activity. The research proposed here is relevant to human health because mutations created by transposons are responsible for over one hundred mendelian diseases in humans. Understanding how transposons are able to avoid being silenced by their host could lead to novel interventions to reduce transposon activity, thereby supporting the NIH’s mission to enhance health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This MIRA project will use theoretical methods, closely coupled with experimental data, to elucidate the basic factors that control the movement of electrons and protons in biological systems, providing fundamental insights into a wide range of biochemical processes essential to living systems. In particular, this project will enhance understanding of the radical translocation mechanism of ribonucleotide reductase, which plays a critical role in DNA synthesis, replication, and repair. The general insights about controlling electrons and protons provided by this work may also have broader implications for protein engineering, drug design, and optogenetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Idiopathic Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a devastating form of interstitial lung disease in adults, is marked by progressive scarring of lung tissue, respiratory failure, and death for which there is a significant unmet need for effective medical therapies. To overcome one of the current barriers in IPF research (a dearth of preclinical models) and to facilitate a better understanding of the fibrotic processes for the identification of new therapeutic targets, we developed two novel mouse models expressing mutations in the Surfactant Protein C (SP-C) gene that are associated with an IPF like syndrome in humans. These highly relevant preclinical models used in conjunction with human IPF lung and serum samples will serve as a comprehensive preclinical platform to identify cell populations, signaling pathways, biomarkers, and the contributions of age and sex on IPF development towards the goal of accelerating the discovery of new IPF treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer in men and the second in women with a worldwide total of over 1.8 million new cases per year. Dietary factors play an important role in CRC because these tumors develop adjacent to the intestinal lumen and receive direct exposure to ingested nutrients, chemicals, and microbiota throughout the day. Fructose consumption is associated with CRC risk and CRC-specific mortality so this proposal will test how the major fructose metabolite, fructose 1-phosphate, alters cellular metabolism to promote tumor cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation (HCT) is a life-saving therapy for the treatment of blood cancers and immune disorders, but complications due to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), an immune response that can affect any organ, limit the long-term benefits of HCT. This proposal explores the highly translational concept that a measurement of the tissues-of-origin of cell-free DNA in the blood circulation enables to detect GVHD and its organ involvement and can predict long-term outcomes of HCT. Successful implementation of these studies will lead to a blood test for the monitoring of GVHD after HCT, which will represent a critical advance in HCT that can lead to better strategies to prevent GVHD and better treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is common, affecting over 700,000 people in the US. It is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system with pronounced axon damage inflicting long-term neurological disability. Accurate assessment of axonal injury early especially in normal appearing white matter is crucially important in therapeutic intervention. For example, we cannot expect remyelination to work on absent or critically injured axons. Thus, the proposed diffusion basis spectrum imaging to model intra-axonal diffusion for improving the sensitivity of detecting axonal injury is of great importance in treating and curing MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Tetraploidization (doubling of the genome) has been proposed to promote tumorigenesis due to the concomitant acquisition of extra centrosomes (key organelles for cell division) during the tetraploidization process. However, this is inconsistent with recent evidence that newly formed tetraploid cells rapidly lose their extra centrosomes, suggesting that the evolution of tetraploid cells may be influenced by specific conditions present in the native tissue and/or in the tumor microenvironment. This project will investigate this possibility by integrating experimental approaches and mathematical modeling to determine which events, cellular processes, and microenvironmental factors are important for the evolution and tumorigenic potential of tetraploid cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic pain is one of the major public health concerns in the US; there is a pressing need to discover and evaluate novel therapeutic targets for pain treatment. Previous studies and preliminary data show that sigma 2/transmembrane protein 97 (σ2/TMEM97) receptor may be a such a novel target. This proposal combines in vivo and in vitro approaches to determine cell-type specific differences in σ2/TMEM97-driven peripheral nociception at the cellular, molecular, and behavioral level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Increasing tuberculosis case detection, especially in high-risk groups, is critical to meet the World Health Organization’s End TB Strategy to reduce tuberculosis incidence by 90% globally by 2035. A significant barrier to achieving this goal is that a large proportion of patients are unable to produce sputum and are therefore are not evaluated with commonly used and recommended diagnostics such as GeneXpert, culture, and smear testing. The overall goal of this proposal is to identify and quantify the burden of undiagnosed tuberculosis in Brazilian prisoners, evaluate the feasibility and value of non-sputum-based diagnostics to improve case detection in this setting, and to identify cost-effective algorithms for tuberculosis screening in prisons.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Veterans must often wait and travel significant distances to receive care from a VA dermatologist. Emerging innovative technologies promise to allow VA to deliver expert skin care to Veterans wherever and whenever they need it. By moving Veterans’ images and histories instead of people, skin concerns can be more rapidly diagnosed and managed remotely by a dermatologist or eventually by a computer trained by artificial intelligence methods. This project will implement a VA-developed teledermatology mobile application at three VA facilities and measure its ability to deliver dermatologic care directly to Veterans in a timely and travel- minimizing manner, and patient and VA staff satisfaction with the process. In parallel, the project will use the data that Veteran patients submit to train and refine artificial intelligence-powered computer vision models whose performance will be tested against dermatologists. The readiness of Veterans and VA to implement these technologies will also be evaluated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although lifelong suppression of HIV replication with antiretroviral therapy (ART) seems possible, side effects, need for strict adherence, resistance, stigma and cost all contribute to the necessity of finding an ‘HIV cure’. As a model for HIV infection, and to better understand viral reservoirs in different organs and cell types, we propose to integrate several novel multi-omic in situ approaches to monkeys infected with the simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV), allowing an in-depth single-cell characterization of viral reservoirs with various levels of residual activity in terms of the expression of viral transcripts. Our ‘panomic’ approach and longitudinal high-density data sets will allow us to develop a comprehensive “atlas” of persistent VR and the cellular immune neighborhoods in which they reside within key organ systems and tissue compartments, and will help identify and characterize novel cellular pathways and factors, phenotypic characteristics and inflammatory immune pathways involved in viral persistence.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-infected patients in the United States now live longer, owing to the effective antiretroviral therapy, but the prevalence of chronic kidney disease continues to increase in this HIV-infected population due to comorbidities with diabetes, hypertension, and HCV. This study will unravel the molecular mechanisms of how chronic HIV infection contributes to the progression of age-related kidney disease, specifically diabetic kidney disease. The knowledge gained will enable the development of effective targeted and personalized therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project is focused on elucidating mechanisms that underlie our sense of touch (somatosensation). Results from these studies will expand our understanding of molecular and cellular mechanisms that contribute to acute and persistent pain. As such, our work will aid in the development of therapeutic strategies (such as novel drugs) for treating chronic pain syndromes and other clinical disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in the way neurons communicate are crucial to brain function, including development, learning and aging. Defects in this neuronal plasticity underlie many neurological disorders, such as autism, epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease. Recently it has become clear that microglia, which are immune cells, are an integral part of brain circuitry and contribute critically to normal brain function and plasticity. Here we will investigate microglial mechanisms that govern changes in neuronal networks. This will yield information with broad implications for understanding and treating a large spectrum of human neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing the incidence of devastating birth defects requires a mechanistic understanding of cell signaling and force transmission in developing tissues. My lab uses Drosophila to investigate force generation by the actomyosin cytoskeleton and its regulation within cells and across tissues. These studies will provide insight into the interplay between contractile signaling and force generation, providing a framework for understanding emergent tissue shapes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gliomas, the most common primary brain tumor in humans, are genetically heterogeneous tumors. Our goal is to credential novel genetically engineered human models of gliomas against patient-derived models using comprehensive biological, molecular, drug therapy profiling. PHR: Project Narrative This research will compare the effectiveness of alert-clinical decision support (CDS) for the management of abnormal glucose in the hospital on clinical, economic and practice performance outcomes in patients admitted to an academic and a community hospital. Anticipating an impactful project, this tool will optimize hospital glucose control and improve patients’ outcomes providing an evidence-based resource to improve patient care. As a subsequent advancement of this alert-CDS, it can be adapted into an electronic medical agnostic tool using standards of interoperability within health informatics to widely benefit many patient across hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  There is excitement that combining engineering and computational disciplines with the life sciences may enable major breakthroughs in the cardiovascular (CV) sciences, yet few training programs exist at this intersection. This new T32 at Stanford provides cutting-edge training for post-PhD, -MD or -MD/PhD fellows combining engineering, CV physiology and medicine that is focused on mentored research, didactics, professional growth, training in diversity, ethics and other key topics. The T32 is well positioned for success due to an excellent pool of applicants, dedicated interdisciplinary faculty, and co-location of top-tier schools of Engineering, Medicine and Humanities and Sciences on a single campus in Silicon Valley.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative:  Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating autoimmune neuroinflammation disease inflicting millions of people worldwide. CD4 T cells, especially Th17 cells, are central to autoimmune neuroinflammation. Our recent findings revealed a novel role for TGF-β superfamily and related signaling to regulate T cell function and the development of autoimmune neuroinflammation. This study aims to reveal previous unappreciated cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying TGF-β superfamily signaling in controlling Th17 cell differentiation and function for autoimmunity. The success of this study will gain critical mechanistic insights into T cell mediated autoimmune neuroinflammation and shed new light on how to mitigate related disease by targeting TGF-β superfamily signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Effective and long lasting antibody responses, which require delicate collaboration of both T and B cells, is essential for immune responses to antigens and successful vaccinations against microbial infections. Using our newly generated mouse models either carrying a CVID patient-derived mutation in SBNO2 or being conditionally deficient of Sbno1, Sbno2, or both, we will illustrate novel mechanisms that control T cell development, homeostasis, and function to shape antibody and anti-viral immune responses. By illustrating the importance of Sbno1/2 in T cells, we will provide novel insight into mechanisms underlying T cell biology and CVID that will guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies against immune-related disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance This project aims to characterize the genetics and molecular biology of a new insulin resistance syndrome associated with overgrowth called insulin-mediated pseudoacromegaly. FGF21 signaling is an exciting area of biology as it promotes insulin sensitivity while simultaneously promoting weight loss. The model systems created in this study will allow us to test drugs that not only have relevance for the patient described in this study, but also for the millions of individuals suffering from the consequences of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Regular physical activity is one of the most important predictors of healthy independent living, but the number of older adults meeting recommended guidelines remains low, especially in lower income communities. This project proposes career development to assist the candidate in developing and testing feasibility of a social network-based physical activity intervention in an affordable (HUD subsidized) senior housing community. This project is the first step in developing a novel low-cost intervention that will work with naturally occurring social resources to increase physical activity in lower income communities and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is an obesity-related condition that affects 1.3 million Veterans, reduces quality of life, and is associated with greater risk of cardiovascular disease. Despite the potential of weight loss to reverse OSA, real-world impact is limited. Veterans seldom receive weight loss services due to a lack of counseling and poor accessibility of current weight loss offerings. Furthermore, there is uncertainty around the benefits of modest weight loss in achieving meaningful outcomes in OSA. To overcome access and knowledge gaps, this trial will examine the effectiveness of a population health approach to weight loss care among Veterans with OSA. We will use a remote lifestyle-based weight loss intervention that is self-directed, low- technology, and likely low cost. We propose a pragmatic trial of proactively delivering this novel intervention among patients with newly diagnosed OSA. We will test whether such an intervention improves weight and meaningful outcomes including sleep-related quality of life, sleep symptoms, and cardiovascular risk.

PHR: NARRATIVE Newly identified regulatory elements across the genome designated as “super enhancer domains” (SEDs) have highly specialized functions in controlling commitment of stem cells to development of a specific cell lineage. The proposed research will, for the first time, characterize SEDs that establish the bone forming osteoblast lineage. These novel genomic regions provide the basis for development of strategies in future studies to regenerate bone tissue in skeletal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance): Chronic pain, drug addiction, anxiety and depression each extract substantial health and socioeconomic costs from the American populace. Although drugs directed toward the kappa opioid receptor (KOR) have been investigated as treatments for these human ailments, they are currently hampered by poor side effect profiles. A deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which the proteins RGS12 and β-arrestin2 regulate the beneficial versus detrimental effects of KOR-directed drugs will enable new strategies to maximize the clinical utility of these (and future) drugs that provide pain relief by targeting opioid receptors, but without addiction or side effect liabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A novel class of long non-coding RNAs that are continuous with and extend far downstream of their upstream protein-coding genes was recently discovered. These RNAs are produced upon innate immune activation from thousands of antiviral genes including the type I interferons, but their function remains elusive. By elucidating the mechanism by which these RNAs regulate the type I interferon response, this study may uncover a new mode of regulation of innate antiviral immunity by previously unappreciated RNA molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Frequently mutated or hyperactivated Notch receptors dysregulate transcription of genes with key functions in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), a heterogenous disease lacking targetable therapeutic options. My research elucidates precise epigenetic mechanisms by which Notch transcription complexes regulate their TNBC target genes. This mechanistic knowledge constitutes an important step toward selective epigenetic targeting of functionally important but “undruggable” genes such as MYC, CCND1 and SOX9 in the Notch-addicted TNBC. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is associated with a dramatic increase in aortic stiffness and subsequent damage to other downstream organs. Since sustained cerebral blood flow is critical, the brain and the vessels of the brain are particularly at risk of injury as a result of higher aortic stiffness. This study will assess how higher levels of aortic stiffness and small vessel dysfunction contribute to early signs of dementia and vascular brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pathogenic protein aggregates are present in most neurodegenerative diseases, and the spread of these aggregates within the brain correlates with disease progression. However, it remains poorly understood how these aggregates spread from neuron to neuron, and elucidating this process could reveal novel therapeutic targets to slow or halt neurodegeneration. This project investigates how mutations in GBA, a gene associated with faster progression of Parkinson's disease, influences propagation of protein aggregates from cell to cell in fruit fly, human neuron and mouse models of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Frailty is a multifactorial syndrome characterized by vulnerability to stressors that is intricately linked to cognitive impairment and mortality risk. Bright light therapy (BLT) reduces circadian disturbances by resynchronizing the hypothalamic biological clock via specific wavelengths of light. Human trials have demonstrated that BLT improves sleep quality and cognitive function in older adults. However, BLT has not been examined for use in older Veteran populations, particularly the impact on frailty. This randomized trial will assess the feasibility of employing BLT to study impacts on frailty, cognition, and sleep in older Veterans. Findings from this pilot will establish the power and effect size necessary for larger trials to support the use of BLT as readily available home-based treatment to improve healthspan of our Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current interpretation of screening mammography suffers from human limitations, leading to approximately 30,000 missed cancers and 3.8 million false positives exams every year in the U.S. alone. Our multidisciplinary team of experts on breast cancer screening, machine and deep learning, data science, and imaging technology assessment will validate our highly accurate 2D mammography artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm that was the best performer in an international competition with >1,200 participants and then further enhance it with novel AI augmentation methods. We will then apply innovative techniques to scale the AI algorithm from 2D to 3D mammography, addressing the issue of a 50-to-100-fold increase in volumetric data with 3D exams, and then clinically translate our optimized AI 3D mammography tool through a series of interpretive accuracy studies involving experienced and inexperienced radiologists from both academic and community practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mechanisms underlying virion assembly of adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors in cells remain poorly understood, and there has been only limited progress in developing new methods to effectively produce AAV vectors at high titers. In this regard, the recent discovery of AAV assembly-activating protein (AAP) has opened a new avenue for AAV research. In this project, by comprehensively studying interactions between AAP, viral capsid protein and host cell proteins, we seek to elucidate the mechanism of virion assembly of AAV vectors in much greater depth, and explore novel strategies that can potentially improve AAV vector production.
