IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) collectively impact approximately 24 million Americans, and cardiovascular disease is one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in this patient population. While subclinical vascular abnormalities such as endothelial dysfunction are prevalent in patients with SLE, the initiating factors that lead to the development of vascular disease remain poorly understood. This project focuses on the role of immune system dysfunction and gut dysbiosis, as well as their interaction, in the pathogenesis of vascular dysfunction in SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac arrhythmias can lead to sudden death in seemingly healthy patients who carry specific mutations affecting proteins of the heart. I propose a state-of-the-art multi-level approach to elucidate the mechanisms of arrhythmia in a model of plakophilin-2 (PKP2) deficiency, which resembles the human disease arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). This research is relevant to public health because it aims to identify potential therapeutic targets to prevent arrhythmia and increase the life expectancy of patients with ARVC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Human skeletal deformities involving the jaw affect ~6% of all adults and are often associated with pain and poor function of the two temporomandibular joints (TMJ) that allow for movement of the lower jaw during talking and eating. Surgery to correct these jaw skeletal deformities, and thus obtain better oral function, is often helpful but can cause problems for the TMJ. This project will determine the biomechanical and biologic conditions of the TMJ for patients with jaw skeletal deformities, both before and after surgery, to understand how these surgeries affect how well the TMJ works and thus aide surgeons to have better surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Pathologies ranging from neurodegeneration to chronic infection have in common the cytoplasmic accumulation of toxins including protein aggregates or whole invading microorganisms. Activation of macroautophagy drives the formation of a new organelle that functions to specifically sequester and eventually destroy these toxins. How this organelle forms, how it closes to complete sequestration and how it delivers its cargo for lysosomal destruction are the major long-term goals of this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The pentameric ligand-gated ion channels (pLGIC) mediate fast synaptic transmission in the central and peripheral nervous systems, and thereby critically govern numerous cellular processes such as pain perception, motor coordination, and gastrointestinal functions. Dysfunctions in pLGIC are associated with several psychiatric, neurological, and gastrointestinal disorders, and therefore these channels are important drug targets. The goal of the proposed studies is to elucidate fundamental mechanisms governing channel function and modulation at a molecular level. Findings from this work will lead to a better understanding of the role of pLGIC in various physiological and pathophysiological processes, and hence aid strategies for development of new and safer therapeutics.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Sebaceous glands secrete oils that are thought to be critical for healthy skin. This proposal seeks to identify factors that modulate sebaceous gland stem cells, and to test the requirement for these glands in maintaining proper skin function. Findings from these studies are relevant to normal skin biology, as well as to pathologies such as seborrheic dermatitis, acne and scarring alopecia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research will provide powerful tools for the synthesis of pharmaceutically relevant compounds and their congeners from readily available alkenes, 1,3-dienes, enynes, and alkynes. Since highly catalytic reactions and readily available precursors are involved in the proposed new processes, successful conclusion of this project will also add to our repertoire of benign synthetic methods useful for large scale manufacture of useful pharmaceutical intermediates. This effort, if successful, will deliver tangible economic and environmental benefits; we hope that the discoveries made will shorten the considerable distance between the conceptualization of a molecule as a drug candidate and its large-scale synthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apicobasal cell polarity is a unique process that generates an extraordinary diversity of epithelia through regulation of cell- cell junctions and the cytoskeleton. How polarity proteins direct spatial organization of different types of cell-cell junctions is a general subject of this proposal. It will uncover the role and mechanisms that are based on polarity proteins of Scrib and Par3 families in organization of two junctional structures Adherens Junctions and Desmosomes. The role of plakophilin family proteins, Pkp2, Pkp3, and Pkp4, in these processes is also under investigation. The study is a critical step toward the development of synthetic modulators of cell-cell adhesion and their application in medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disease with no effective treatment. Based on studies indicating a strong link between the insulin-like growth factor (IGF) system and AD, we propose to generate an AD mouse model lacking a unique enzyme that regulates local IGF action (PAPP-A). We hypothesize that deletion of PAPP-A protects against AD-like pathology and cognitive impairment, and, if so proven, would support the development of novel therapies for AD based on targeted inhibition of PAPP-A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated one third of human populations are chronically infected with the human pathogen, Toxoplasma gondii. Chronic toxoplasmosis cannot be prevented as there is no current treatment that eliminates the dormant tissue cyst in infected individuals. In this proposal, we will use a new innovative ex vivo model of tissue cyst reactivation to define the cellular and molecular basis of chronic disease, and thereby, open new avenues of research into new treatments that can prevent and cure chronic toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance  The proper coding of head movements by the inner ear vestibular epithelia depends upon communication between hair cells and afferent neurons through specialized subcellular structures known as synapses. The scientific tasks to be conducted through this project aim to develop critical methodologies required to investigate the structure-function relationship of individual synapses within the mammalian vestibular neuroepithelia. This work is critical to future studies designed to elucidate the alterations associated with many pathologic conditions and potential treatments targeting the pathologies to these critical sites.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with comorbid chronic pain and depression are highly prevalent, have poor functional status and low quality of life, are at increased risk of suicide and lack access to effective treatments. To address this problem, the proposed research will examine the feasibility of a novel approach that integrates repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy with the overall goal of maximizing functional improvement in Veterans with chronic pain and depression. This is an important first-step in preparation for a future randomized efficacy trial. We will also include two cognitive control tasks with concurrent electroencephalography to explore as a potential objective indicator of treatment response. This application addresses a critical need within the Veterans Health Administration and is closely aligned with the focus area of developing suicide prevention treatments that influence participation in life roles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-sensitive or -resistant varieties, is the major cause of skin/soft tissue infections and is being identified with greater frequency as the cause of more serious infections like endocarditis. Within the infection site, S. aureus can scavenge and use host-derived fatty acids to satisfy its lipid biosynthesis needs, but we do not yet understand the prevalence of these exogenous fatty acid in the S. aureus membrane or the impact they may have on antimicrobial therapies. In this project, we will determine the effects of host- derived fatty acids on the lipid composition, membrane physiology, and antibiotic tolerances of S. aureus with the goal of preventing treatment failures in internal organ and systemic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) are two devastating chronic lung diseases with distinct clinical features, which may be due to genetic differences. In fact, there are at least five regions of the genome (loci) where the genetic variants that increase the risk of developing COPD decrease the risk of developing IPF. We plan to characterize how these “COPD/IPF opposite risk loci” contribute to gene expression changes in specific lung cells, which will give us new knowledge about the biology of COPD and IPF, both of which are lacking effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to the public because treatment resistant depression (TRD) is increasing in prevalence and represents a significant national cost. Motivated by our recent findings of decreased levels of acetyl-L- carnitine (LAC) in TRD, we seek to understand the role of central and peripheral mitochondrial metabolism of LAC in the effects of TMS-related effects on resting state functional connectivity and clinical responses. This work will lead to development of new multidimensional models of brain-body metabolic crosstalk and development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The heart pumps blood into the systemic system by contracting cardiac muscle during systole, which is initiated by a rise in intracellular calcium concentration that triggers sliding of the thick and thin filaments in the muscle sarcomere. Myosin is the molecular motor that uses the energy from ATP hydrolysis to drive filament sliding and mutations in myosin can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, a common form of heart failure that disrupts systolic contraction. This proposal will investigate the impact of dilated cardiomyopathy mutations on several aspects of human beta-cardiac myosin structure and function, including the regulatory mechanism, structural mechanism of force generation, and ability to drive filament sliding in a calcium dependent manner.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Peng proposes to comprehensively investigate breast cancer and its treatment (chemotherapy, radiation, and hormone therapy) with global and domain-specific cognitive trajectory over time and to characterize cancer hallmark pathways in brain tissues of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients and controls to identify intersecting mechanisms for cancer and AD to inform targeted intervention. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) death is extremely high in type 1 diabetes, and insulin resistance predicts CVD in these individuals. This research will investigate, in participants with type 1 diabetes, the impact of glucagon like peptide-1 receptor agonism and exercise training on microvascular dysfunction, a common condition which worsens insulin resistance and may reduce exercise tolerance and fitness. The results of this investigation will provide important mechanistic insight into microvascular dysfunction in type 1 diabetes and examine an adjuvant treatment modality to improve it, which could have important public health implications for improving exercise tolerance, insulin resistance, and CVD in the future.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: RELEVANCE Although the risk of hypertension increases in women at menopause the biological mechanisms underlying this increased hypertension susceptibility is uncertain. Using a multidisciplinary strategy incorporating sophisticated approaches we will investigate the brain mechanisms of menopausal hypertension using a novel model of accelerated ovarian failure in mice. A better grasp of the mechanisms underlying the emergence of hypertension associated with ovarian failure will aid in developing more effective diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for the gender-specific management of blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Nephrotic syndrome (NS) is an important cause of progressive renal failure with the notable exception of Minimal change disease (MCD), which is highly responsive to treatment in spite of having podocyte cytoskeletal injury similar to other NS. We identified AMP-kinase as a specific signal in MCD podocytes which enables their survival in spite of injury. Our work here will study a large case series of human NS to establish innovative diagnostic methods for MCD based on AMPK activity that will also have prognostic value, and use pharmacologic and genetic models to develop and repurpose AMP-Kinase activators for use in all NS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Many middle-aged and older adults who live with multimorbidity report abandoning their medications or skipping doses because of cost. Patients are unable to account for medication costs when making medical decisions, because they rarely know what those costs will be before getting to the pharmacy. Under the guidance of her mentors, Dr. Sloan will evaluate the uptake and acceptability of a novel clinician-facing out-of-pocket price transparency tool, as well as its impact on clinical outcomes and adherence among middle-aged and older adults with multimorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dietary factors and metabolic disorders such as obesity and diabetes are increasingly contributing to pancreatic cancer diagnoses. Understanding how diet intersects with metabolism in the pancreas will expand the general knowledge of how cancer cells rewire their metabolism and how this may influence their progression to tumors. Targeting metabolic pathways in the pancreas in combination with dietary regulation may provide much needed therapies to prevent the development of pancreatic cancer and slow its growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research will provide novel information on vector stoichiometry and vector competence of a medically important mosquito. Comprehensive knowledge of the ecology of Aedes aegypti and its dengue vector competence is fundamental for implementing efficient control practices and developing technology that protects public health in tropical and subtropical regions where the species is present. More so as cities continue to expand, and global temperatures becomes warmer contributing to the species dispersal. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases (ADs) affect over 25 million Americans, inflicting tremendous individual suffering and societal burdens. Exposure to the earth’s most abundant mineral, crystalline silica (quartz), is common in individuals involved in construction, mining, farming, manufacturing and military deployment and increases their risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus) and other ADs. Here we seek to understand the underlying mechanisms by which consumption of the omega-3 fatty acid docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) blocks silica-triggered lupus, thus yielding important new insights into how environmental toxicants trigger AD and how manipulating the lipidome through dietary fatty acid supplementation can prevent it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Time-based interventions, such as time-limited eating, have been shown to be a promising dietary strategy for weight loss, glucose and lipid metabolism improvements, and overall well-being in adults with type 2 diabetes, however no study has investigated time-limited eating in adolescents with type 2 diabetes. Because of its simplicity, time-limited eating may represent a more flexible, non-stigmatizing, and low-cost approach for adolescents than other caloric restriction regimens. This project aims to determine if time-limited eating in adolescents with type 2 diabetes minimizes glycemic excursions, delays β-cell deterioration, and reduces body fat mass compared to a prolonged eating period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability to create new intracellular membrane compartments de novo is a fundamental aspect of eukaryotic cell behavior. Disruption of processes that involve de novo assembly are implicated in many pathological syndromes including ciliopathies and neurodegenerative diseases. Understanding the mechanisms of membrane assembly and expansion is therefore important for human health. The process of sporulation in budding yeast provides an excellent model in which to study de novo membrane formation. The experiments in this proposal are focused on understanding the molecular events required for initiation of a new membrane compartment on the yeast spindle pole body and how the Vps13 lipid transfer protein promotes expansion of that membrane.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response appears is a universal feature of all cardiomyopathies as well as healing after cardiac injury or disease initiation. Here we have identified a novel function for thrombospondin1 (Thbs1) as an intracellular regulator of the ER stress response that then leads to enhanced cardiac atrophy thorugh a specific signaling mechanism with the ER and that effects autophagosome formation. Understanding how and why Thbs1 has this unique molecular function is of medical relevance as many forms of heart disease are associated with ventricular remodeling and loss of tissue mass.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Anxiety is highly prevalent, distressing and disabling among those with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) as well as care partners. Moreover, anxiety appears to accelerate the development of cognitive decline among those with MCI but there is not an established treatment with potential for high dissemination, broad reach, and low participant burden that can be easily delivered at point-of-care settings. The current proposal builds upon existing work by evaluating the efficacy of a brief intervention that can significantly reduce anxiety and related distress in MCI/ADRD and care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Release of the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate depends on its storage inside synaptic vesicles. However, the ions important for glutamate uptake fluctuate dramatically as synaptic vesicles undergo exo- and endocytosis. We will now determine how the unusual properties of vesicular glutamate transport that we have identified serve to coordinate vesicle filling with events in the synaptic vesicle cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  We aim to provide a causal link between a fundamental cortical computation (i.e. gain control), specific cell types and perceptual states. The dysregulation of cortical gain control has been strongly implicated as a cause of neuropsychiatric diseases such as autism and schizophrenia. Thus, linking this computation to the impact of specific cell types on both network activity and perceptual states is a necessary step in identifying the source of dysfunction and constraining the set of interventions that may be used in treatment of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is designed to use a biobehavioral approach, a stress-coping model, a culturally sensitive framework, and innovative methods in psychoneuroimmunology to provide novel information about how bereavement increases cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk, including detecting relevant ethnic disparities and identifying protective factors that promote resilience during this difficult life transition. Results from this project will provide critical evidence to inform the development of culturally and contextually sensitive interventions aimed at reducing disease burden in a vulnerable population. The longitudinal design will provide valuable information to identify critical time points for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to further our understanding of endometrial cancer survival outcomes and survivorship experiences for Latina women through an exploratory sequential mixed methods approach. This study will have a positive impact on cancer disparities research by advancing the knowledge of the macro/systemic level contexts that influence and shape endometrial cancer survival outcomes and survivorship experiences among Latina women. Findings from this research will help to inform public health research and practice interventions to improve survivorship experiences and will set up future research inquiries to further examine endometrial cancer survival and survivorship among Latina women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Parkinson’s disease is an irreversible neurodegenerative disease that is among the fastest growing neurological diseases in prevalence, associated disability, and death. Because cell death is irreversible, identifying early disease-events is critical for developing treatments that act before the brain is damaged beyond repair. The loss of axons of dopamine neurons in the Substantia Nigra pars compacta is one such early event, and the goals of this project are to better understand how subcellular molecular and functional specialization of mitochondria contribute to axon survival, and whether these processes are altered in mouse models of Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several neurodevelopmental disorders arise from defects in neurogenesis and neuronal migration. Though some work has been done, the underlying processes that contribute to normal neural development and the pathological mechanisms in disease remain not entirely known. This proposal focuses on using advanced bioinformatic analyses and molecular manipulations to understand how the meninges, a protective covering for the central nervous system, regulates brain development, how the failure of meninges formation impacts aberrant brain development and identify potential therapeutic strategies to help patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Spanish speakers represent approximately 75% of all children learning two languages in the United States, yet there is a lack of tools to assess the home language of these bilingual children. The proposed project will develop a Spanish grammatical productivity measure to capture the emerging language abilities of young bilingual children (Aim 1) and evaluate the use of this Spanish measure in the reports of caregivers through a culturally adaptative framework (Aim 2). The results of this project will improve language assessment by informing how bilingual children, with and without a language disorder, produce Spanish grammar, and how caregiver reports on grammatical productivity can be used to characterize bilingual children’s language development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: T cell receptors and antibodies are exceptionally diverse and capable of engaging broad arrays of antigens, and are of high interest as therapeutics and in the study of immune response to diseases and viruses. My laboratory will generate robust modeling and design frameworks, utilizing large curated datasets of structures assembled by my laboratory and machine learning methods, to accurately predict structures of T cell receptors from sequence, model T cell receptor and antibody antigen recognition, and design T cell receptors and antibodies with desired targeting capabilities. These new tools will be made available to the community, and will be applied to model and design antibodies and T cell receptors of medical and therapeutic interest.

PHR: Circadian biological clocks work in all cells of the human body to regulate access to the genome, metabolism, development, and cell division. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Isolated adult-onset focal dystonia causes disability and negatively impacts quality of life and employment status; available treatments are limited due to incomplete benefit, invasive application, or poor tolerance. The goal of this study is to better understand the brain mechanisms that contribute to isolated dystonia, which may provide rationale for new treatments. This study is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission to develop a fundamental knowledge of disease to improve symptomatic relief and reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis causes destruction of the tooth-supporting tissues and its prevalence and severity increases with aging. Del-1 is a secreted homeostatic protein that regulates periodontal inflammation and bone formation, although its expression is diminished in old age. This project investigates the consequences of the aging- related deficiency of Del-1 on periodontal bone regeneration and proposes approaches to improve the regenerative capacity of the periodontal tissue in old age.

PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma is a highly heterogeneous and lethal human brain tumor that contains stem-like cells (GSCs) that contribute to tumor initiation, development, growth and resistance to conventional therapies. If successful, the proposed project would provide information on a new REST-miR-124-miR-203 mechanism-based therapeutic approach for stratified High REST-GSC tumor subtype in combination with standard-of-care temozoomide and ionizing radiation. It would also reveal treatment-dependent transcriptome signatures, providing mechanistic information about affected downstream targets and pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affects 1.6—3.1 million Americans and is associated with significant lifetime morbidity as well as a heavy financial burden to society. Our current understanding of the factors that initiate and propagate inflammatory changes within the intestine is limited. The current proposal is designed to investigate how abnormalities in mitochondrial function and cellular metabolism within the intestinal epithelium contribute to disease in the hopes of identifying novel therapeutic strategies for IBD aimed at improving mitochondrial health in the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Research Experience in Autism for College and High School students (REACH) is an eight-week pipeline summer course for minorities and underrepresented students interested in the field of neuroscience. REACH is an immersive, team-based and peer-mentoring program that provides students with research training in Autism Spectrum Disorders complemented with lecture, clinical and career development instruction. REACH’s long- term goal is to increase access and retention of underrepresented minorities into the neuroscience/biomedical field and their representation and decision-making influence within our nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are numerous ultra-small size bacteria in our bodies called TM7 that live on the surface of other typically known and studied bacteria, making them difficult to study in the laboratory. These bacteria are linked to periodontal disease in the oral cavity and various inflammatory diseases throughout the body, but when it comes to their role in these diseases, we have an extremely limited understanding. Our research is focused on systematically examining the pathogenesis of these ultra-small bacteria with its host bacteria, thereby contributing to the fundamental knowledge about these newly recognized bacteria in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Our selection of foods we consume is governed in large part by taste pathways in the periphery (sweet, salty, sour, etc). However, there is a paucity of information about the molecular identities of afferent sensory neurons that process taste signals and transmit these signals to the brain. Understanding how basic tastes are encoded by sensory neurons whose molecular profiles are known is key for understanding diet selection and making rational choices of what we eat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: The proposed research will investigate the functional roles of electrostatic interactions in the regulation of transcription and translation in bacteria and their biofilm communities, which due to their notorious tolerance to antibiotics pose a critical public health threat. In particular, we aim to establish a new paradigm for understanding how electrostatic interactions in bacteria can regulate cell fate decisions, such as the entry into, and exit from dormancy, which is the major cause of bacterial tolerance to antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Synaptic connections between neurons are required for all human behavior, and new experiences are encoded in brain circuits by altering their performance. This project aims to assess previously unexplored features of synapses that may allow their performance to be adjusted in heretofore unexpected ways, and will thus help understand the biological basis of memory formation. Further, because mental illness frequently arises from aberrant synapse function, these experiments will help determine the origin and potential treatments for diseases including schizophrenia and autism.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stroke is a common condition that causes weakness of one side of the body but it is difficult to predict how much recovery happens, where and when rehabilitation should happen, and what ultimate living situation is best. There is as potential for wearable devices (such as activity monitors) to help the medical team better make decisions about rehabilitation and provide patients and their families with information about recovery. We propose to test a set of wearable devices that measure movement, muscle activation, and sweating (which is a measure of effort and stress,) in veterans who are admitted to the hospital for stroke. The data from these wearables will be analyzed and compared to standard tests of function, using machine learning techniques. We expect that movement during daily and even nighttime activity will provide useful information that will enable better decision-making in cases of new strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The intestinal lining consists of different types of cells that are specialized to absorb nutrients and water, produce mucus or otherwise contribute to a functional intestine. We propose that tuft cells, a type of these lining cells, are specialized to recognize different types of infection such as parasitic or bacterial infection, and orchestrate the immune response accordingly. In our experiments we will elucidate the unknown role of tuft cells in bacterial infection, which will help to understand how intestinal inflammation is triggered and lay the foundation for better treatment of intestinal infectious and inflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is highly successful in suppressing viral replication and preventing disease progression, however, it does not eradicate HIV. Standard ART does not fully restore health or a normal immune status in people living with HIV (PLWH) and co-morbidities such as cardiovascular disease and cognitive impairment may occur. Efforts to identify strategies to eradicate or induce treatment-free long-term HIV remission are critical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging and recalcitrant fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, have significantly risen in recent years. As no licensed fungal vaccines are available, our work aims to uncover the basis of fungal vaccine immunity, and identity of a protective surface marker that has profound implications of T-cell based vaccine-efficacy. Our work is of translational in nature, and will serve as a guide to other fungal vaccine platforms tailored for immunocompromised individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall - Project Narrative The ability to produce blood cells is necessary throughout life, requiring hematopoietic developmental programs guided by cell-intrinsic and -extrinsic mechanisms conveying the need for these cells. The Program seeks to yield a transformative understanding of the role of glycosylation and glycans (cell surface sugars) in regulated blood cell production, in health and in disease. This knowledge will be leveraged to find novel therapeutic targets and therapeutics to promote hematopoietic health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans with Serious Mental Illness (SMI) struggle with social integration - participation in work, housing, and citizenship - due to symptoms, stigma, and psychosocial functioning deficits. This has a tremendous impact on mortality, comparable to that of smoking and greater than obesity and alcohol abuse. While the VA has made considerable efforts to provide mental health care to Veterans with SMI, programs that promote social integration are lacking. This project targets an especially vulnerable group, Veterans with SMI experiencing psychosis, with a peer support-based group approach. This virtual innovation is based on efforts from a consumer-driven, global social movement called the Hearing Voices approach. We seek to adapt and standardize this approach within the VA context via the development of a manual, training program for VA mental health clinicians and peers, and fidelity scale, which will then be piloted with 30 Veterans in 5 groups of 6 Veterans over the course of 20 weeks. This information will support the design of a controlled efficacy study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients on hemodialysis have high rates of hospitalizations. Yet, social determinants of health (economic instability, education, neighborhood and built environment, social and community context, and health and healthcare access), which have previously been demonstrated to be associated with hospitalization in hemodialysis patients, are not easily identified and used in research. We plan to identify these factors using prospective surveys and natural language processing software on electronic health records, where these factors are routinely documented, and add these factors to standard clinical factors in complex machine learning models to identify patients at higher risk for hospitalization, and in the process train Dr. Lili Chan into an independent clinical investigator in the field of “big data” research in nephrology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Adults with traumatic brain injury (TBI) have persistent deficits in using and processing language in context, but commonly used methods to detect these deficits in clinical and research settings lack the required sensitivity and have focused on a limited subset of discourse tasks that do not reliably predict communication outcomes. Using ecologically valid language tasks and methods sensitive enough to detect even subtle, though meaningful, disruptions in language, the proposed work endeavors to show that deficits in contextual language processing in TBI extend even to the rapid processing of individual phrases and sentences in the moment (i.e., online processing), can be captured in controlled settings, and that such deficits are a predictor of communicative outcome. This proposal is unique in the field and uniquely promising for understanding the nature of deficits in contextual language processing following TBI and, ultimately, improving rehabilitation intervention outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will inform guidelines needed to promote healthy gestational weight gain (GWG) in women with severe obesity, for whom current guidelines may be inappropriate. This study will use data from a unique populations of low-income mothers and children served by community health centers across the U.S. to investigate GWG patterns, specific to the degree of maternal obesity severity, that minimize risk of adverse birth outcomes, rapid infant growth, and childhood obesity in the offspring, and reduce racial and ethnic disparities in childhood obesity. The proposed research will (1) provide evidence needed to improve strategies for early prevention of obesity and (2) generate evidence aimed at alleviating the disproportionate burden of obesity in low-income and racial/ethnic minority women and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To adequately account for the role of stereochemistry and conformational variation in biological systems and their impact on health, new high resolution, high-throughput separation modalities are necessary. Our research program develops a new tandem ion mobility platform that integrates innovative electrode arrangements and drive electronics to prepare ions for laser dissociation at elevated pressures and provide new levels of analytical detail. With a focus on cost-effective and accessible solutions to enhance analytical performance, we envision broad adoption of this co-planar, traveling wave ion mobility system due to its ultra-high resolution capabilities and integrated fragmentation stages which directly address bioanalytical challenges across disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE By combining cutting-edge human imaging techniques with olfactory psychophysics approaches, “virtual reality” methods, and model-based analyses in healthy human subjects, the proposed research will generate new insights into the behavioral and neural substrates of odor navigation in the human brain. By addressing the “where” question of the human sense of smell, our work will uniquely extend the limited available data on how humans can use their noses to orient and path-find within an odorous landscape. Finally, insofar as deficits in the sense of smell often emerge as an early sign in Alzheimer’s disease, and which is often accompanied by visuospatial impairments and deficits of real-world navigation, the research findings obtained here may yield novel olfactory-based mechanistic frameworks for reorienting patients to their environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Policies and interventions that seek to reduce the incarceration of individuals with serious mental illness and reduce the role of law enforcement in responding to mental health crises are of great importance to public health. To inform and facilitate evaluation of these policies and interventions, we will further the development of a large, existing, continually-updated county-wide dataset linked across 8 public agencies in Los Angeles County, which will (a) facilitate research that can identify and evaluate strategies for improving access, continuity, and equity of mental health services among some of the most vulnerable and potentially unserved individuals with serious mental illness and (b) facilitate ongoing monitoring of access, service continuity, equity, and outcomes such as incarceration and homelessness in diverse populations and settings. We will work with partners from Los Angeles County agencies and researchers from other geographic areas to develop approaches for identifying key information in the data—individuals with serious mental illness; key events such as mental health diversion services, alternative crisis services, arrests, and incarcerations; episodes of outpatient mental health services or homelessness; and service patterns before or after key events—and we will test the use of these linked data and approaches in an evaluation of alternative mental health crisis services in Los Angeles, in preparation for future research on policies and interventions that seek to reduce incarceration and law enforcement response to individuals with serious mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by impairments in the motivation to engage in social interactions. By using novel computational tracking system with a novel rodent model of social self- administration in rats with a mutation in the Shank3 gene (a rat model for ASD), in combination with cutting- edge tools and circuitry manipulation approaches, this proposal will determine the behavioral and neural mechanisms mediating the autism-like-induced shift in social motivation. This research will provide collaborative potential and introduce new ideas and a new conceptual framework to ASD research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wnt growth factors controls many aspects of digestive system development, stem cell homeostasis and cancer, where it is an important therapeutic target. How Wnts control different genetic programs in different cells is an important unanswered question. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: We propose a mixed methods study to evaluate the impact of VA-financed community care for Veterans with advanced kidney disease, and to identify subgroups within this population most likely to benefit and most likely to be harmed by receipt of nephrology care in the community. These patients comprise a high-cost high-needs segment of the Veteran population facing a critical health and care transition (onset of end-stage renal disease). The work we here propose is highly relevant to the VA mission (it will directly address three VA HSR&D priority areas), timely (the VA MISSION Act recently received strong bipartisan support in both the House and the Senate), and will directly inform evolving VA policy around the provision of community care for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a herpesvirus that remains a significant global health problem with no permanent effective therapy. The proposed study will investigate a potential relationship between HCMV and the host enzyme telomerase, a key regulator of a cell’s chromosomes and survival. Defining the importance of telomerase in the HCMV viral life cycle will enhance understanding of HCMV and similar herpesviruses, guide development of a permanent effective anti-viral therapy, and improve clinical management of HCMV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has the potential to impact positively the lives of individuals with intractable depression. Converging lines of theoretical evidence have identified two fiber bundles in the subcallosal cingulate (SCC) as probable therapeutic targets of SCC DBS, and this study's goal is to test this connectomic hypothesis with computational rigor and electrophysiological validation using the latest computational framework for precision DBS. Rigorous computational standards and tools that can be disseminated to other groups working on SCC DBS can help simplify and objectivity the process of parameter selection in future clinical studies.

PHR: The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that mitochondrial dysfunction and increased inflammation mediates age-related kidney disease. We propose that a) increased expression of estrogen related receptors ERRα and ERRγ improves mitochondrial function, and decreases cGAS-STING signaling, cellular senescence and inflammation, which reverses age-related kidney disease; b) the effects of ERRs on senescence, inflammation, and fibrosis are cGAS-STING dependent; c) increased expression of ERRα and ERRγ or inhibition of cGAS-STING signaling prevents acute kidney injury mediated by folic acid, LPS, or ischemia/reperfusion

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  MEHMO syndrome is a recently identified X-linked intellectual disability syndrome that presents with characteristic symptoms including: Mental deficiency, Epilepsy, Hypogenitalism, Microcephaly, and Obesity. MEHMO syndrome is caused by mutations in a core member of the cellular protein synthesis machinery; however, the causal links between mis-regulated protein synthesis and human disease remain poorly understood. The successful completion of the research proposed here will provide a thorough understanding of how protein synthesis is modulated in a global and gene-specific manner by a MEHMO syndrome mutation, and identify key factors contributing to the MEHMO syndrome phenotypes that could significantly aid in the development of therapeutics and improved strategies for patient treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is aimed at defining how disruption of the circadian clock, both genetic and environmental, accelerates colorectal cancer pathogenesis using mouse models and patient-derived intestinal organoids. We propose that the circadian clock regulates signaling and proliferation pathways as well as rewired metabolism to drive transformation of the intestinal epithelium. Our molecular studies will provide new insight towards prevention strategies and targeted therapeutic approaches for the treatment of colorectal cancer that rely on pharmacological modulation of the circadian clock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease, and the age is a major factor for the most case of AD, but the mechanisms underlying the link between age and AD is still unclear. In this project we will use mouse models and human postmortem tissue to examine a novel epigenetic mechanism that effects on aging and AD, and whether changes of epigenetic regulation in aging could steer normal aging toward AD development. The information derived from the project will help to develop new prevention and treatment strategies that benefit AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Word finding difficulty (verbal retrieval deficit) is one major language sequela of traumatic brain injury (TBI), with effective treatment still lacking. The pre-Supplementary Motor Area (pre-SMA) has an important role in verbal retrieval and may be modulated by high-definition transcranial direct current stimulation (HD-tDCS) to remediate verbal retrieval deficits. The proposed study will use HD-tDCS to modulate the pre-SMA in order to treat TBI-related verbal retrieval deficits, and the overall aims are to 1) examine underlying mechanisms based on synchronized neuronal activity measured by electroencephalography (EEG), 2) examine how white matter integrity of two pre-SMA associated tracts important for verbal retrieval affects HD-tDCS induced improvement, and 3) develop predictive models based on mechanisms that will guide selection of better responders for HD- tDCS intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The cochlea is the part of the inner ear that responds to sounds and is the primary organ for our sense of hearing. The proposed research program will develop a computational simulation of cochlear mechanics that addresses a fundamental question regarding amplification in the cochlea. In addition, results from cochlear models will be combined with physiological and behavioral data from human subjects to support the investigation of specific auditory phenomena, such as acoustic reflections from the cochlea, speech-consonant perception, and multi-tone loudness growth. Thus, the proposed research combines human measurements and computer simulations to address important questions about hearing processes that have both basic scientific and applied clinical relevance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is an innovative approach to an unmet need in the treatment of hematological malignancies: the inability to target malignant stem cells, the source of relapse and disease progression. We discovered a new druggable target molecule that can specifically reduce the number of malignant stem cells in primary myelofibrosis caused by the JAK2V617F mutation. If successful, this application will address the urgent need to develop treatments that specifically target JAK2V617F stem cells to produce better long-term outcomes than current therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune related adverse events from immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICPIs) are particularly challenging in the Emergency Department (ED) because of atypical presentations, the absence of classic symptoms, delayed availability of diagnostic tests during the ED encounter, and the fast pace in the ED setting. This patient-cen- tered project aims to develop and prospectively validate a probability model [Immune-related Emergency Dis- position index (irEDi)] that integrates immune/inflammation markers that are readily available in the ED with demographic, biological, cancer, treatment, and clinical data at the ED to guide ED disposition (Hospital admis- sion; observation; or discharge) in a multi-center cohort study of ED patients on ICPIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schizotypal personality disorder (SPD) is similar to schizophrenia (SZ), but with fewer and attenuated abnormalities, representing an important yet understudied intermediate SZ-spectrum phenotype that provides important information regarding etiology, genetics, treatment and risk factors associated with psychosis. This study utilizes a Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) approach coupled with longitudinal multimodal MR imaging and neurocognitive assessment in SZ-spectrum disorders to identify aberrant neural circuitry and cognition along a continuum from healthy controls to SPD (in the SZ spectrum but not fully psychotic) to SZ (psychosis). Changes in frontal-temporal regions/circuitry and neurocognitive measures over time will be examined together using novel approaches (e.g., machine learning) to predict diagnostic group, symptom severity, and functional outcome for the identification of key factors associated with risk and resilience in the SZ spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to determine the functional connectivity and behavioral roles of subcortical-to- hippocampal CA3 projections, including the basolateral amygdala-to-CA3 and supramammillary nucleus-to- CA3 inputs. Given the strong involvement of CA3 in a range of neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as posttraumatic stress disorders (PTSD), depression, chronic stress, and epilepsy, the knowledge gained from this proposal will provide novel insights into its normal functions and provide a foundation for future studies to explore the role of these pathways in mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The pressing need to understand sleep is underscored by the major clinical and economic impact of sleep disorders: 10-15% of the U.S. population suffers from chronic insomnia, and nearly one hundred sleep disorders have been described, including narcolepsy, sleep apnea, and delayed and advanced sleep phase syndromes. Molecular genetic studies that began in Drosophila have already allowed mutant orthologs of Period proteins, casein kinase 1, and Cryptochromes to be connected to inborn errors of human sleep. We believe our proposed genetic, cellular, and biochemical studies of Drosophila will continue to provide insights and tools relevant to the understanding of human sleep, and will complement our deepening, direct investigations of human sleep genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative A diverse range of biological phenomena requires the precise and coordinated control of gene expression. We recently identified NDF, an evolutionarily conserved, novel RNA Polymerase II (Pol II) transcription factor. In this project, we will address molecular mechanisms of NDF- mediated Pol II transcription, which will increase the breadth and depth of our understanding of the regulation of eukaryotic transcription through chromatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Among all organs in the body, we understand the brain least–we still do not know how the brain controls movement. This work seeks to uncover explanations on how the brain controls voluntary movement in settings like walking and running. This new insight will be critical to developing better recovery treatments for people with movement disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When a child has a stroke, the injury to the brain can cause seizures immediately and epilepsy later after the brain heals. The “Seizures and Children's Outcomes after Stroke (SCOUTS)” study will help us understand how inflammation is related to both early seizures and epilepsy, and the networks in the brain that are most vulnerable to epilepsy after a child has a stroke. We will use this knowledge to provide more accurate prognoses early after a stroke and to select promising anti-inflammatory treatments to study for prevention of post-stroke epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Glaucoma is the second most common cause of blindness in the U.S. and the most common cause of blindness among African-Americans. An elevation in intraocular pressure caused by the restriction of aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork is a common risk factor. The goal of this project is to identify signaling pathways that contribute to the restriction in outflow facility and determine if inhibiting these mechanisms can be used as potential therapies to increase outflow facility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The formin family of proteins nucleates and directs the elongation of unbranched actin filaments that are incorporated into a variety of specialized bundled actin structures, enabling cells to perform essential processes such as division, motility and transport. Mutations in formin genes are associated with a number of human diseases including neurological disorders, microcephaly, dilated cardiomyopathy, and cancer. By elucidating a detailed understanding of the relationship between the physical properties of formins and their biological functions, we seek to gain insight into the large number of cellular processes regulated by formins and establish a molecular basis for understanding formin-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Deaths linked to opioid addiction are at an all-time high in the United States, and 50% of users relapse within three months of treatment, taking drugs to avoid aversive states linked to craving, withdrawal, negative emotions, and stress. There is a crucial need to understand impairments in brain circuitry driving these states at the outset of treatment and how they track patterns of recovery (abstinence versus relapse) within users, and between users and healthy individuals, during these pivotal first three months. Research on brain mechanisms of early recovery could serve to inform future targets for intervention (e.g., novel brain neurofeedback treatments) and aid the development of a precision medicine approach to reduce drug-related deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: People with temporal lobe epilepsy undergoing surgical procedures targeting the medial temporal lobe are at high risk for post-surgical memory decline, yet techniques for accurately predicting memory decline are lacking. Patients implanted with intracranial electrodes during inpatient seizure monitoring present a unique opportunity to leverage neurostimulation to induce a functional lesion and map memory-critical structures. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the spatial specificity of neurostimulation for functional lesion mapping during memory testing with the ultimate goal of developing a reliable protocol for individualized prediction of memory outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary loss-of-function variants in the CTNNA1 gene may be associated with increased risk of gastric and/or breast cancer, however the breadth and magnitude of the cancer risks associated with this gene remain poorly understood. This study will define the cancer penetrance in CTNNA1 loss-of-function variant carriers and will develop laboratory assays to further refine these cancer risks in a variant-specific manner. The combined results from this work will enable variant-specific CTNNA1 cancer risk determination, which will lay important groundwork to allow for appropriate clinical management of cancer risk in CTNNA1 loss-of-function variant carriers as well as their family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer survivors suffer high rates of body image-related distress which results in significant psychosocial morbidity and decreased quality of life. However, effective therapies to manage this disorder among head and neck cancer survivors are lacking. We have developed a novel, scalable, tele-cognitive behavioral therapy intervention for head and neck cancer survivors with body image-related distress that could provide the first effective treatment in this population, thereby minimizing psychosocial morbidity, improving quality of life, and developing new standards of clinical care.
